description: In the CHFI series, Daniel and Adam will take you through all the concepts, tools, and best-practices you'll need to know for the CHFI exam. You'll be introduced to many different digital forensic techniques and duties like safely copying hard drives, how to perform as a "First Responder", searching for and recovering deleted files, steganographic techniques, common attack avenues, acting as an expert witness, and much more.

26

Adam, could you tell us
also a little bit about

this would be a great way

its response in forensics

the other EC counsel related training or

And if that sounds like something that

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take time to look at the state of computer forensics in today's world. episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.744
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.744 --> 00:00:02.651

3
00:00:02.651 --> 00:00:07.107
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.107 --> 00:00:08.842
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.842 --> 00:00:11.897
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:11.897 --> 00:00:13.215
>> All right, greetings everyone.

7
00:00:13.215 --> 00:00:16.500
And welcome to another
great episode of ITPRO.TV.

8
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:17.580
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:17.580 --> 00:00:23.159
And in today's episode, well we
are kicking off our CHFI version 9 series.

10
00:00:23.159 --> 00:00:25.840
And joining us in the studio,
the man, the myth, the legend.

11
00:00:25.840 --> 00:00:27.550
You know him as Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:28.590
Adam, welcome back sir.

13
00:00:28.590 --> 00:00:29.450
How's it going?

14
00:00:29.450 --> 00:00:30.160
>> Good, good.
Thank you.

15
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:32.480
Version 9,
because it's better than version 8.

16
00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:33.580
>> Right.
>> That's what we're going with.

17
00:00:33.580 --> 00:00:34.560
>> Now with more versioning.

18
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:37.050
>> Now with more versioning,
than we have with version 8.

19
00:00:37.050 --> 00:00:38.150
So glad to be back.

20
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:39.910
Glad to be spending time
with you as always.

21
00:00:39.910 --> 00:00:41.530
We're gonna start talking about CHFI.

22
00:00:41.530 --> 00:00:44.540
Very exciting area of knowledge and
content.

23
00:00:44.540 --> 00:00:48.630
Hopefully you'll find it to be so,
Computer Hacking Forensics Investigation.

24
00:00:48.630 --> 00:00:53.458
Generically computer forensics, you hear
it often referred to as digital forensics.

25
00:00:53.458 --> 00:00:56.890
What we're gonna be spending time
on talking about working with and

26
00:00:56.890 --> 00:00:59.760
thinking through,
is the logic of how we do

27
00:00:59.760 --> 00:01:04.440
investigations on computer related crimes,
crimes that involve computers.

28
00:01:04.440 --> 00:01:08.117
Hacking incidence for instance,
people that who have used computers to

29
00:01:08.117 --> 00:01:10.658
achieve some nefarious,
and whatever it may be.

30
00:01:10.658 --> 00:01:14.462
And the methodological procedures and
techniques that help us to identify,

31
00:01:14.462 --> 00:01:18.793
gather, preserve, extract, interpret,
document and ultimately examine evidence

32
00:01:18.793 --> 00:01:22.948
from multiple perspectives is really what
computer forensics will be all about, or

33
00:01:22.948 --> 00:01:24.460
what we will focus on.

34
00:01:24.460 --> 00:01:27.020
And most importantly in ways
that are legally admissible.

35
00:01:27.020 --> 00:01:28.390
It's not just enough to say hey,

36
00:01:28.390 --> 00:01:31.930
by the way we wanna go out,
we wanna gather evidence.

37
00:01:31.930 --> 00:01:33.850
Cuz we could certainly do that.

38
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:38.380
But if we do it in a way that is not
perceived in a court of law according

39
00:01:38.380 --> 00:01:42.390
to the rules of evidence to be legitimate,
and therefore allowable, admissible.

40
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:43.960
It's the term that we will use.

41
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:47.080
Then whatever we have done,
the activities will engaged in and

42
00:01:47.080 --> 00:01:50.180
the fruits of that labor will enforce
should be read or null and void.

43
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:52.162
We will not in other words,
have access to the information.

44
00:01:52.162 --> 00:01:56.735
We'll not be able to leverage in use that
information in order to further prosecute

45
00:01:56.735 --> 00:02:00.584
or to pursue any leads that come from
that, or to pursue a case in a court

46
00:02:00.584 --> 00:02:04.833
of law, and potentially bring somebody
before the court seeking justice for

47
00:02:04.833 --> 00:02:07.040
wrongs they may have committed.

48
00:02:07.040 --> 00:02:10.920
And you see this on TV, you see this in
movies all the time, as part of a story

49
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:15.380
line where somebody does somethings,
there is then an investigation.

50
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:16.910
And if a rule, whatever the rule may be,

51
00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:20.420
whatever the story line is,
perhaps it's not followed correctly.

52
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:25.630
Maybe the law enforcement, people legal
agents were acting on behalf of them.

53
00:02:25.630 --> 00:02:28.760
Whatever the case was,
did not get a search warrant, or

54
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:31.680
did get a search warrant, but
exceeded the scope, the boundary,

55
00:02:31.680 --> 00:02:33.240
and the coverage of the search warrant.

56
00:02:33.240 --> 00:02:37.960
Or maybe because of extenuating
circumstances, they went ahead and

57
00:02:37.960 --> 00:02:39.560
engaged in certain activities.

58
00:02:39.560 --> 00:02:42.860
And then had to validate before
a judge that those activities and

59
00:02:42.860 --> 00:02:44.780
the things they did were warranted.

60
00:02:44.780 --> 00:02:48.870
Were allowed because of extenuating or
what we call exigent circumstances.

61
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:50.140
All these variations.

62
00:02:50.140 --> 00:02:52.138
>> Adam,
I've watched plenty of gritty cop dramas.

63
00:02:52.138 --> 00:02:55.200
And I'll know,is all you have to do
is say I heard someone yell for help.

64
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:56.135
And then you can go and
do whatever you want.

65
00:02:56.135 --> 00:02:58.227
[LAUGH]
>> Well you can do that,

66
00:02:58.227 --> 00:02:59.150
that is very true.

67
00:02:59.150 --> 00:03:02.890
But doing whatever you want,
all kidding aside, we're joking, but

68
00:03:02.890 --> 00:03:05.900
raises a really interesting
point under the thought process,

69
00:03:05.900 --> 00:03:08.760
around the thought process
as we interpret this.

70
00:03:08.760 --> 00:03:11.050
The idea is that yes,
what we just described,

71
00:03:11.050 --> 00:03:13.190
what we call exigent circumstance, right?

72
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:17.890
Situational things that are happening
that normally we would say,

73
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:20.020
hey you are not allowed to go
break open that door, right?

74
00:03:20.020 --> 00:03:23.135
But somebody yelling, help,
I'm being held hostage, help,

75
00:03:23.135 --> 00:03:25.740
someone's got a gun to my head,
whatever they yell.

76
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:30.264
Or you believe as a law enforcement
officer that somebody is about

77
00:03:30.264 --> 00:03:33.060
to either have bodily harm done to them or

78
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:37.601
something someone will be harmed
irreparably if you don't act.

79
00:03:37.601 --> 00:03:39.081
You have a little room,

80
00:03:39.081 --> 00:03:43.500
right, under the interpretation
in law to be able to take action.

81
00:03:43.500 --> 00:03:45.050
But that doesn't mean
that you can do anything.

82
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:46.438
>> Right.
>> It means that you are allowed to do

83
00:03:46.438 --> 00:03:47.320
certain things.

84
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:48.810
You are allowed to go in and investigate.

85
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.910
You are allowed to try to
safe guard that life, right?

86
00:03:51.910 --> 00:03:54.550
We can stop somebody from
trying to shoot somebody

87
00:03:54.550 --> 00:03:57.990
by shooting them if there's
a clear threat, present danger.

88
00:03:57.990 --> 00:04:02.702
But that doesn't mean we can then go and
broadly search, and do anything we wanna

89
00:04:02.702 --> 00:04:06.738
do within that scene until we have
established certain parameters.

90
00:04:06.738 --> 00:04:09.192
Until we understand better
what has happened, and

91
00:04:09.192 --> 00:04:13.359
until depending on the circumstances, we
may have received additional permission in

92
00:04:13.359 --> 00:04:16.841
the form of writing, typically
a search warrant, from an authorized,

93
00:04:16.841 --> 00:04:20.435
in this case probably a court of law
judge, has issued a warrant that says,

94
00:04:20.435 --> 00:04:22.410
yes you're allowed to go search.

95
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:26.570
Now if it's a crime scene we happen on
after the fact, very different, right?

96
00:04:26.570 --> 00:04:31.090
We walk in, and there are unfortunately
bodies, perhaps laying on the ground.

97
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:34.460
Somebody's been harmed,
there's clear evidence of a crime.

98
00:04:34.460 --> 00:04:38.150
We at that point may be able to operate
differently, we're able to investigate,

99
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:41.780
we're able to go look in the pockets of
the person that may have been harmed that

100
00:04:41.780 --> 00:04:45.630
was attacked, because now they're part of
what happened, part of the crime scene.

101
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:49.090
So it does depend on circumstances,
as you rightly point out.

102
00:04:49.090 --> 00:04:52.790
And it depends on what we are being
asked to do in the circumstances,

103
00:04:52.790 --> 00:04:56.930
or then surround the circumstances
that we find ourselves to be involved.

104
00:04:56.930 --> 00:04:59.920
I'll have a lot more to say about
that in coming discussions.

105
00:04:59.920 --> 00:05:02.956
But the objectives of
computer forensics overall,

106
00:05:02.956 --> 00:05:05.721
thinking through the logic
of what we wanna do.

107
00:05:05.721 --> 00:05:08.400
I'm gonna actually put a list up here.

108
00:05:08.400 --> 00:05:10.690
If you just bear with me for
one second, there we go.

109
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:13.170
If we can go full screen,
just so you can see this.

110
00:05:13.170 --> 00:05:15.210
That way we don't cut
off there on the margin.

111
00:05:15.210 --> 00:05:18.100
And a lot of this stuff we'll talk
about in these beginning episodes is

112
00:05:18.100 --> 00:05:20.180
gonna involve me throwing
up a list of things.

113
00:05:20.180 --> 00:05:23.350
Especially as we get into the rules
of evidence, and talk through them.

114
00:05:23.350 --> 00:05:24.810
Because there's just a lot of verbage,

115
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:27.650
and a lot of detail that you
wanna make sure you're aware of.

116
00:05:27.650 --> 00:05:30.240
All of this is in the show notes,
obviously encourage

117
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:34.870
you as we always do to take a look and
use those as a guide to help you prepare.

118
00:05:34.870 --> 00:05:37.340
Not only to apply this
knowledge in the real world,

119
00:05:37.340 --> 00:05:40.690
but those of you that may be looking
to go on and perhaps study for and

120
00:05:40.690 --> 00:05:45.220
take one or more exams in this case to see
at your final exam, you would wanna use

121
00:05:45.220 --> 00:05:49.470
this information to help you to prepare,
so objectives of computer forensic.

122
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:53.800
Not an exhaustive list, but
certainly a major point list if you will.

123
00:05:53.800 --> 00:05:57.580
Things that are very likely to be
considered main objectives are on this

124
00:05:57.580 --> 00:05:59.310
list, and identifying, gathering, and

125
00:05:59.310 --> 00:06:02.810
preserving evidence of a cyber
crime in this case, right?

126
00:06:02.810 --> 00:06:04.180
Would be at the top of the list.

127
00:06:04.180 --> 00:06:08.340
Tracking and prosecuting perpetrators
that may have executed this crime in

128
00:06:08.340 --> 00:06:12.060
whatever court of law has jurisdiction,
wherever the crime was committed we

129
00:06:12.060 --> 00:06:16.370
would seek to then gain
access to the court there and

130
00:06:16.370 --> 00:06:20.270
prosecute a case if appropriate,
if we have evidence, if we are allowed to.

131
00:06:20.270 --> 00:06:23.410
In that jurisdiction,
we'll talk more about jurisdiction and

132
00:06:23.410 --> 00:06:27.960
the ability to be able to deal with the
specific interpretation of law by country

133
00:06:27.960 --> 00:06:29.610
in upcoming conversations as well.

134
00:06:29.610 --> 00:06:32.570
But remember, law generically

135
00:06:32.570 --> 00:06:36.030
is the same everywhere we go in
the sense that almost without exception,

136
00:06:36.030 --> 00:06:42.090
every country will have a set of laws that
addresses things like what is a crime?

137
00:06:42.090 --> 00:06:43.330
How was it committed?

138
00:06:43.330 --> 00:06:47.150
Under what circumstances do we or don't
we have the right to seek redress and

139
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:50.800
to prosecute a court or
rather prosecute a crime that occurred?

140
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:53.590
But every country will interpret
their laws differently,

141
00:06:53.590 --> 00:06:57.140
will apply them differently, and
will draft them differently.

142
00:06:57.140 --> 00:07:00.180
And as a broad statement, not every
country will be different because many

143
00:07:00.180 --> 00:07:02.650
countries come from the perspective or

144
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:06.430
share the perspective of a common
foundation for their legal systems,

145
00:07:06.430 --> 00:07:10.890
whether it's common law under the English
system or whatever the case may be.

146
00:07:10.890 --> 00:07:12.950
And as a result,
there's a lot of similarity there.

147
00:07:12.950 --> 00:07:16.290
But there are unique differences and
subtle differences that we need to be

148
00:07:16.290 --> 00:07:22.410
aware of as forensics experts,
as investigators, as representatives of

149
00:07:22.410 --> 00:07:26.880
a process that allows us to gather
information and allows us to do so

150
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:31.550
on a forensically sound and appropriate
way following the rules of evidence.

151
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:33.990
Whatever they may be
based on the locality and

152
00:07:33.990 --> 00:07:35.970
the legal jurisdictions enforced there.

153
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:39.470
And following and establishing
a chain of custody of evidence for

154
00:07:39.470 --> 00:07:42.580
an important term that we'll come
back to time and again here.

155
00:07:42.580 --> 00:07:45.820
We have to follow the rules in other
words and play the game correctly.

156
00:07:45.820 --> 00:07:48.468
To then seek the end game that
we're looking for, and hopefully,

516
00:25:57.525 --> 00:26:01.037
We'd wanna be collecting all
this kind of information and

517
00:26:01.037 --> 00:26:03.624
understanding what that information is.

518
00:26:03.624 --> 00:26:06.307
If we don't have a good background and
baseline for that,

519
00:26:06.307 --> 00:26:08.661
may be very difficult for
us to certify the system,

520
00:26:08.661 --> 00:26:11.620
and to then introduce information
about it into evidence.

521
00:26:11.620 --> 00:26:13.760
So it is important to consider that.

522
00:26:13.760 --> 00:26:15.200
Or we may not be able to
tell the complete story,

523
00:26:15.200 --> 00:26:16.360
is probably another way
to think about that.

524
00:26:16.360 --> 00:26:18.764
And we do have to bear
that in mind as well.

525
00:26:18.764 --> 00:26:22.988
So electronic evidence consists of any
number of things that are gathered,

526
00:26:22.988 --> 00:26:27.674
both volatile and non-volatile data that
points to the current state of the machine

527
00:26:27.674 --> 00:26:31.832
and the alternate state, the state that
it was in prior to being modified or

528
00:26:31.832 --> 00:26:32.838
being attacked.

529
00:26:32.838 --> 00:26:35.955
And the current state now in the delta,
the gap between the two,

530
00:26:35.955 --> 00:26:38.923
all of that information helps
us to tell a compelling story.

531
00:26:38.923 --> 00:26:40.725
And so we wanna make sure
that we're aware of that.

532
00:26:40.725 --> 00:26:45.490
We've talked about chain of custody and
how important chain of custody is.

533
00:26:45.490 --> 00:26:49.680
When we think about chain of custody, we
are thinking about the ability to be able

534
00:26:49.680 --> 00:26:53.240
to tell the story of where that evidence
has been, under whose control, for

535
00:26:53.240 --> 00:26:56.780
how long, and in what circumstances
from the time it has been tagged and

536
00:26:56.780 --> 00:26:59.550
bagged until the time it is
given back to whoever owns or

537
00:26:59.550 --> 00:27:02.510
is destroyed at the end of the need for
it.

538
00:27:02.510 --> 00:27:05.770
Every moment in between must be accounted
for unequivocally without exception.

539
00:27:05.770 --> 00:27:08.029
And we've talked about
the importance of chain of custody.

540
00:27:08.029 --> 00:27:10.700
We've also talked about the fact that
we often have chain of custody forms.

541
00:27:10.700 --> 00:27:13.900
Thought it would be good to show you
what a chain of custody form looks like.

542
00:27:13.900 --> 00:27:15.220
Again, couple of samples here.

543
00:27:15.220 --> 00:27:17.850
If we can go full-screen,
just to show you this.

544
00:27:17.850 --> 00:27:20.500
So this one, just a Word document.

545
00:27:20.500 --> 00:27:24.460
You can see evidence chain of custody
tracking form, case number, right?

546
00:27:24.460 --> 00:27:28.557
Submitting officer, this is the police
thought processor one geared around

547
00:27:28.557 --> 00:27:30.582
a police department, so you can see.

548
00:27:30.582 --> 00:27:33.720
It's got specific law enforcement
references, like victim, suspect,

549
00:27:33.720 --> 00:27:35.870
date/time seized, location of seizure.

550
00:27:35.870 --> 00:27:39.775
And then, information about the evidence
and then chain on custody, right?

551
00:27:39.775 --> 00:27:44.530
So you could see here that we
have the item number, date, time,

552
00:27:44.530 --> 00:27:47.860
released by, signature, and id number,
some sort of unique tracking number.

553
00:27:47.860 --> 00:27:49.447
Maybe a badge number in this case,

554
00:27:49.447 --> 00:27:52.313
or whatever it may be,
since it's a police officer, right?

555
00:27:52.313 --> 00:27:54.720
Received by, comments, location, and

556
00:27:54.720 --> 00:27:57.625
that's just a chart that
goes down as you can see.

557
00:27:57.625 --> 00:28:01.820
And then, the tracking from just
continues and kind of just is used there.

558
00:28:01.820 --> 00:28:06.032
And then final disposition authority,
right, authorization for disposal.

559
00:28:06.032 --> 00:28:09.139
This item pertaining to this case,
this suspect etc.,

560
00:28:09.139 --> 00:28:13.753
is either being returned to owner or is
being auctioned, destroyed, or diverted.

561
00:28:13.753 --> 00:28:15.551
There's different options,
outcomes, again,

562
00:28:15.551 --> 00:28:17.920
depending on the nature of
the organization that has this.

563
00:28:17.920 --> 00:28:21.036
Who's signing that they're giving them
the authority to be able to do that.

564
00:28:21.036 --> 00:28:23.090
Witness to destruction, so
if you are destroying it,

565
00:28:23.090 --> 00:28:25.674
you have to have a witness that
says it really was destroyed.

566
00:28:25.674 --> 00:28:27.318
Yeah, I got rid of all that cash,
I burned it.

567
00:28:27.318 --> 00:28:29.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Of course you did, right?

568
00:28:29.070 --> 00:28:31.070
Absolutely, all the drugs when
in the bonfire, your honor,

569
00:28:31.070 --> 00:28:32.234
absolutely, no problem, right?

570
00:28:32.234 --> 00:28:33.924
>> That's right, I promise.

571
00:28:33.924 --> 00:28:34.940
>> Absolutely, right?

572
00:28:34.940 --> 00:28:39.430
Or release to lawful owner here, you
could see items in the document, right,

573
00:28:39.430 --> 00:28:41.040
were released to the lawful owner.

574
00:28:41.040 --> 00:28:44.800
So you can see here that there is
a lot of stuff that has to happen.

575
00:28:44.800 --> 00:28:48.624
Now, in addition, we may have a slightly
different take on this, evidence property,

576
00:28:48.624 --> 00:28:49.406
you can see here.

577
00:28:49.406 --> 00:28:51.170
I'm gonna just zoom in here for
one second.

578
00:28:52.730 --> 00:29:00.040
So you can see this one, and this one
is going to be one for the military.

579
00:29:00.040 --> 00:29:03.620
And so this is
a US Army Criminal Investigative Command,

580
00:29:03.620 --> 00:29:08.850
the CIC, evidence or property custodial
document, very similar, right?

581
00:29:08.850 --> 00:29:11.860
Law enforcement entity within the Army,
in this case.

582
00:29:11.860 --> 00:29:16.350
But again, you have a receiving activity,
you have a location.

583
00:29:17.700 --> 00:29:20.185
You've got the name and grade and
title of the person who received it.

584
00:29:20.185 --> 00:29:23.940
So essentially, who the intake
officer was, the address, all that.

585
00:29:23.940 --> 00:29:26.710
Where it's obtained, reason,
time, date, item, and quantity,

586
00:29:26.710 --> 00:29:28.770
could see all that here.

587
00:29:28.770 --> 00:29:30.820
Then the chain of custody information.

588
00:29:30.820 --> 00:29:33.610
Instead of badge number or
unique identifier,

589
00:29:33.610 --> 00:29:35.639
you see a name, grade, or title.

590
00:29:35.639 --> 00:29:38.854
Cuz this is the military,
probably gonna be Sergeant so and so,

591
00:29:38.854 --> 00:29:41.200
Colonel so and so, or whatever.

592
00:29:41.200 --> 00:29:43.293
And so we're gonna have that.

593
00:29:43.293 --> 00:29:45.760
So we have that purpose
of change of custody.

594
00:29:45.760 --> 00:29:47.153
Why are we doing this, right?

595
00:29:47.153 --> 00:29:50.275
Has to be documented there,
all of these, right?

596
00:29:50.275 --> 00:29:52.870
Just kind of chart as we go down.

597
00:29:52.870 --> 00:29:56.660
There's the final disposition action,
final disposition authority,

598
00:29:56.660 --> 00:29:57.850
witness to destruction of evidence.

599
00:29:57.850 --> 00:29:59.540
Standardized thought process,

600
00:29:59.540 --> 00:30:03.810
those boxes, that information in some form
is gonna appear in every one of these.

601
00:30:03.810 --> 00:30:07.037
And you're going to see that
regardless of who creates the form,

602
00:30:07.037 --> 00:30:11.613
whether it's law enforcement, whether it's
military, whether it's a private entity,

603
00:30:11.613 --> 00:30:15.486
you should have those standard things
because those are the things that we look

604
00:30:15.486 --> 00:30:19.386
for and that we audit for and we verify,
should be in the document at all times.

605
00:30:19.386 --> 00:30:22.680
This is the standardized way,
the templated way that we do this.

606
00:30:22.680 --> 00:30:25.350
This is one of those things that there
is a right and a wrong way to do.

607
00:30:25.350 --> 00:30:28.540
The right way is the form that you've
seen, the wrong way would be to modify

608
00:30:28.540 --> 00:30:32.270
that in detail, or rather,
deviate from that by leaving things out or

609
00:30:32.270 --> 00:30:36.500
not fully filling it out or not fully
having it documented that everybody that

610
00:30:36.500 --> 00:30:39.750
touched the information or
the item had to sign in and sign out.

611
00:30:39.750 --> 00:30:41.080
That would be the wrong way.

612
00:30:41.080 --> 00:30:43.670
The right way would be to have a form
that looked something like this, and

613
00:30:43.670 --> 00:30:46.520
to follow this and implement this
standard this particular way.

614
00:30:46.520 --> 00:30:48.060
So, wanna make sure we're aware of that.

615
00:30:48.060 --> 00:30:51.450
But essentially, a legal document that
demonstrates a progression of evidence

616
00:30:51.450 --> 00:30:53.900
from the time it is gathered
until the time it is disposed of

617
00:30:53.900 --> 00:30:56.450
is what the chain of custody
is going to represent for us.

618
00:30:56.450 --> 00:30:59.770
The forms can be introduced in
a court of law to validate.

619
00:30:59.770 --> 00:31:02.470
And an evidence log that people did or

620
00:31:02.470 --> 00:31:05.840
did not come into contact with the
evidence at certain points in time, right?

621
00:31:05.840 --> 00:31:07.740
So it's very important for
us to think about that.

622
00:31:07.740 --> 00:31:11.690
What is the most important rule that
we can think about, verbalize, and

623
00:31:11.690 --> 00:31:16.500
talk about with regards to the forensic
process and the management of evidence?

624
00:31:16.500 --> 00:31:17.260
Anybody, anybody?

625
00:31:17.260 --> 00:31:17.890
Bueller, Bueller?

626
00:31:17.890 --> 00:31:19.140
>> Do unto others.

627
00:31:19.140 --> 00:31:19.815
>> Do unto others.

628
00:31:19.815 --> 00:31:21.750
>> [LAUGH] Right, it's the Golden Rule.
>> Not quite, right?

629
00:31:21.750 --> 00:31:24.720
Instead of do unto others,
it would be do unto copies,

630
00:31:24.720 --> 00:31:26.060
as opposed to do unto originals, right?

631
00:31:26.060 --> 00:31:26.638
>> That's right.

632
00:31:26.638 --> 00:31:27.830
>> You never do unto originals.

633
00:31:27.830 --> 00:31:30.301
In other words, never, ever,
ever use original evidence.

634
00:31:30.301 --> 00:31:31.940
You always use copies of evidence.

635
00:31:31.940 --> 00:31:35.041
Because remember, as we've talked about,
you only get shot at being an original.

636
00:31:35.041 --> 00:31:36.920
After that, you are no longer an original.

637
00:31:36.920 --> 00:31:39.838
You are a pale imitation, and
if we screw up the original, we're done.

638
00:31:39.838 --> 00:31:41.647
>> A poser.

639
00:31:41.647 --> 00:31:44.131
>> You are exactly that,
we are done, right?

640
00:31:44.131 --> 00:31:47.909
And so we have to understand and be aware
of the fact we never get a second chance

641
00:31:47.909 --> 00:31:50.890
to put that pristine evidence
back together again, right?

642
00:31:50.890 --> 00:31:52.420
It's gotta be kept pristine.

643
00:31:52.420 --> 00:31:53.700
We cannot use it.

644
00:31:53.700 --> 00:31:56.560
We can take copies of it,
forensically sound copies can be made.

645
00:31:56.560 --> 00:32:00.080
That is an acceptable and
allowable methodology and approach.

646
00:32:00.080 --> 00:32:02.570
And we encourage the use of that approach.

647
00:32:02.570 --> 00:32:05.570
And then, once that's done,
make as many copies as you need.

648
00:32:05.570 --> 00:32:06.560
Validate them, hash them,

649
00:32:06.560 --> 00:32:10.420
create the integrity cross walk,
ensure that they are legitimate copies.

650
00:32:10.420 --> 00:32:13.310
And then, go to town on those and
do whatever you wanna do to them.

651
00:32:13.310 --> 00:32:16.610
Carve them up, break them,
throw them away, make as many as you need.

652
00:32:16.610 --> 00:32:17.474
Crunch will make more.

653
00:32:17.474 --> 00:32:18.326
>> That's right.
>> As they used to say, right?

654
00:32:18.326 --> 00:32:19.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we could do that.

655
00:32:19.780 --> 00:32:21.670
But you gotta work on the copies,
not the original.

656
00:32:21.670 --> 00:32:23.277
Very important for
you to be aware of that.

657
00:32:23.277 --> 00:32:27.120
>> That's right, never ever ever,
again, we can't reiterate it more.

658
00:32:27.120 --> 00:32:30.981
Definitely never use the original because
you'll lose the integrity, right?

659
00:32:30.981 --> 00:32:33.594
It starts casting that shadow
of doubt on whether or

660
00:32:33.594 --> 00:32:35.490
not the original has been modified.

661
00:32:35.490 --> 00:32:38.117
>> It's a black hole of doubt,
there's no shadow.

662
00:32:38.117 --> 00:32:39.153
It is a black hole of doubt, right there.

663
00:32:39.153 --> 00:32:43.080
>> Yes, yes, we don't want that, so
nothing but copies, that's right.

664
00:32:43.080 --> 00:32:45.120
Make those copies, modify the copies.

665
00:32:45.120 --> 00:32:45.630
Adam thanks for

666
00:32:45.630 --> 00:32:48.650
showing us the cool resources on
doing the tagging and bagging.

667
00:32:48.650 --> 00:32:50.778
Very cool stuff to see those forms and

668
00:32:50.778 --> 00:32:54.495
what they look like to see what you
can expect to have to fill out.

669
00:32:54.495 --> 00:32:57.247
And the detail that goes
into those things is very,

670
00:32:57.247 --> 00:33:01.026
very important to make sure that
they're all done in the correct way,

671
00:33:01.026 --> 00:33:04.117
and like Adam said,
not modified for your own purposes.

672
00:33:04.117 --> 00:33:05.865
That's not what we wanna get
in the business of doing.

673
00:33:05.865 --> 00:33:07.990
You wanna stick to the standard.

674
00:33:07.990 --> 00:33:12.690
That being said, we have plenty more to
go in this topic, but we are out of time.

675
00:33:12.690 --> 00:33:14.655
So we're gonna have to come back for,
I think, we're in Part 6 now.

676
00:33:14.655 --> 00:33:15.984
>> You know what the scary part is?

677
00:33:15.984 --> 00:33:18.447
We're at half of it now.
>> I know, there's a lot of information,

678
00:33:18.447 --> 00:33:21.330
but it is necessary information for
you folks out there.

679
00:33:21.330 --> 00:33:23.848
So join us in Part 6, we'll be back.

680
00:33:23.848 --> 00:33:28.855
Or as I like to call it, Part 5,
Part 2 [LAUGH] right, for that one.

681
00:33:28.855 --> 00:33:30.230
>> Third book, second implementation.

682
00:33:30.230 --> 00:33:33.593
>> Exactly, exactly, so as for
this episode, we're gonna go ahead and

683
00:33:33.593 --> 00:33:34.398
close her down.

684
00:33:34.398 --> 00:33:35.613
Thanks for watching everyone.

685
00:33:35.613 --> 00:33:38.610
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

686
00:33:38.610 --> 00:33:39.739
>> I am Adam Gordon.

00:33:39.739 --> 00:33:40.898
>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.855
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.855 --> 00:00:08.319
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:12.020
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.020 --> 00:00:17.151
>> All right, greetings, everyone, welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:17.151 --> 00:00:20.549
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:20.549 --> 00:00:23.167
we are back with more on
our CHFI version 9 series.

7
00:00:23.167 --> 00:00:25.307
It just tastes so good,
we had to have a little bit more.

8
00:00:25.307 --> 00:00:29.264
And joining us back in the studio yet
again, our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:29.264 --> 00:00:31.935
Adam, glad to have you again
to continue this conversation.

10
00:00:31.935 --> 00:00:33.232
>> Thank you, always glad to be here.

11
00:00:33.232 --> 00:00:37.329
I brought my appetite with me, so because
it's tasty, we'll jump right in and

12
00:00:37.329 --> 00:00:41.550
take a nibble of privacy, and privacy
related search and seizure concerns.

13
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:45.025
As an investigator, as a CHFI,
as we've been talking about,

14
00:00:45.025 --> 00:00:46.674
in our prior conversations.

15
00:00:46.674 --> 00:00:50.571
We've been going through the logic, the
thought process of some of the legalities

16
00:00:50.571 --> 00:00:54.070
around how we operate,
what the investigative process looks like.

17
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:56.945
Its methodology, but also,
what are the federal rules of evidence

18
00:00:56.945 --> 00:00:59.115
in the United States that
govern our behavior, and

19
00:00:59.115 --> 00:01:00.489
how do we address those things?

20
00:01:00.489 --> 00:01:03.689
Searching and
seizing is part of that conversation,

21
00:01:03.689 --> 00:01:06.260
do we have the right to do so, absolutely.

22
00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:09.684
Do we have the right to do so with or
without a warrant, it depends.

23
00:01:09.684 --> 00:01:13.730
So we really have to understand what may
or may not be allowed based on something

24
00:01:13.730 --> 00:01:18.107
we've talked about already, this concept
of exigent circumstance that comes up.

25
00:01:18.107 --> 00:01:22.109
Where perhaps there are circumstances
happening in the real world at

26
00:01:22.109 --> 00:01:25.421
the moment that we are involved
in looking for evidence,

27
00:01:25.421 --> 00:01:30.044
or finding out that there is something
going on that may require our attention,

28
00:01:30.044 --> 00:01:32.882
that could lead to
the destruction of evidence.

29
00:01:32.882 --> 00:01:36.989
And if that is the case, we may be able
to act without a search warrant, without

30
00:01:36.989 --> 00:01:40.975
the legal permission from a judge that
says it is allowable for you to go in and

31
00:01:40.975 --> 00:01:45.350
search for these things in this area
at this time under these circumstances.

32
00:01:45.350 --> 00:01:47.290
So we have some opportunity here,

33
00:01:47.290 --> 00:01:51.780
there is some what we would call carved
out space or room that we can operate in.

34
00:01:51.780 --> 00:01:55.450
But we have to be very specific,
we have to be very detailed and understand

35
00:01:55.450 --> 00:02:00.150
the exact boundaries, parameters of what
we are allowed and are not allowed to do.

36
00:02:00.150 --> 00:02:02.746
And keep in mind that when
we're talking about this,

37
00:02:02.746 --> 00:02:06.266
we're primarily exclusively really
talking about law enforcement and

38
00:02:06.266 --> 00:02:09.395
their representatives operating
in a search and seizure mode.

39
00:02:09.395 --> 00:02:13.530
This is not a private citizen going in and
attempting to search for evidence.

40
00:02:13.530 --> 00:02:18.200
This is a law enforcement official that
would normally need a search warrant, or

41
00:02:18.200 --> 00:02:22.942
a duly appointed representative of the law
enforcement officials that would need

42
00:02:22.942 --> 00:02:24.055
a search warrant.

43
00:02:24.055 --> 00:02:29.126
And under certain circumstances,
may act without that warrant, in order to

44
00:02:29.126 --> 00:02:34.470
preserve evidence and to take care of or
safeguard life as well as property.

45
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:36.800
Due to whatever compelling situation or

46
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:39.916
compelling circumstances in
that situation may be going on.

47
00:02:39.916 --> 00:02:43.330
So if the government's
conduct does not violate

48
00:02:43.330 --> 00:02:47.370
a person's reasonable expectation
of privacy, as we define it,

49
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:51.640
then formally we do not have an issue with
the Fourth Amendment in the United States.

50
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:55.920

00:36:29.869 --> 00:36:32.580
they have enough evidence that
they think you're up to no good,

730
00:36:32.580 --> 00:36:36.015
that they're coming with 25 of
their friends to come visit you?

731
00:36:36.015 --> 00:36:37.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> If that's the case,

732
00:36:37.330 --> 00:36:40.768
they are gonna assume that you're
gonna try to blow the evidence up, or

733
00:36:40.768 --> 00:36:42.120
somehow modify it.

734
00:36:42.120 --> 00:36:45.962
And they have the ability to act
to safeguard that evidence, and

735
00:36:45.962 --> 00:36:47.963
if you don't comply, trust me.

736
00:36:47.963 --> 00:36:50.425
They will shoot you first and
worry about where you fall later.

737
00:36:50.425 --> 00:36:54.750
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> But that's how it works, so

738
00:36:54.750 --> 00:36:56.015
we need to understand that.

739
00:36:56.015 --> 00:36:58.423
Degree of urgency,
amount of time to obtain a warrant,

740
00:36:58.423 --> 00:37:00.180
will evidence be removed or destroyed.

741
00:37:00.180 --> 00:37:03.737
Are the key defining characteristics
with regards to exigent circumstance, so

742
00:37:03.737 --> 00:37:04.949
we need to be aware of that.

743
00:37:04.949 --> 00:37:08.204
And finally,
we talked about the plain view concept and

744
00:37:08.204 --> 00:37:10.880
the exception around plain view.

745
00:37:10.880 --> 00:37:14.337
Evidence in plain view may be
seized with or without a warrant.

746
00:37:14.337 --> 00:37:16.821
Excuse me, without a warrant,
excuse me, but

747
00:37:16.821 --> 00:37:19.440
computer files that
are seized may not be opened.

748
00:37:19.440 --> 00:37:20.650
This is kind of interesting.

749
00:37:20.650 --> 00:37:23.340
Again, we're talking
specifically about computers.

750
00:37:23.340 --> 00:37:26.812
We could seize the evidence, but we can't
look at the files and examine them,

751
00:37:26.812 --> 00:37:28.810
unless we're already authorized to do so.

752
00:37:28.810 --> 00:37:32.940
So what will often happen is,
we will seize a computer in plain sight,

753
00:37:32.940 --> 00:37:35.679
say, okay, ours, evidence, do not touch.

754
00:37:35.679 --> 00:37:39.990
Nobody will examine that computer until
you actually have a search warrant.

755
00:37:39.990 --> 00:37:41.001
>> That's interesting.

756
00:37:41.001 --> 00:37:45.711
>> So because of the plain view exception,
we can essentially encumber the evidence,

757
00:37:45.711 --> 00:37:47.251
the machine, the entity.

758
00:37:47.251 --> 00:37:51.540
But we cannot look at it, examine it,
unless we have legal right to do so.

759
00:37:51.540 --> 00:37:53.325
>> So if they don't give the legal right,
then they just have to return it.

760
00:37:53.325 --> 00:37:56.008
>> Then essentially it sits there and
nobody's able to do anything with it,

761
00:37:56.008 --> 00:37:58.013
if they cannot obtain a search
warrant after the fact.

762
00:37:58.013 --> 00:37:58.764
>> Interesting.

763
00:37:58.764 --> 00:38:02.025
>> Yes, so you are not able to do that,
that's right.

764
00:38:02.025 --> 00:38:03.041
>> [LAUGH]
>> Again,

765
00:38:03.041 --> 00:38:05.557
it's kind of interesting-
>> It's probably a really good thing to

766
00:38:05.557 --> 00:38:08.506
know, because if I was an investigator and
I snatched that as evidence, and

767
00:38:08.506 --> 00:38:11.010
I didn't have a warrant And
I searched it without that warrant.

768
00:38:11.010 --> 00:38:12.757
>> For instance, you sat down-
>> Now all of a sudden, yeah.

769
00:38:12.757 --> 00:38:14.692
>> Yeah, you see this all
the time on TV and movies, right?

770
00:38:14.692 --> 00:38:17.610
Again, you look at this stuff,
you're like, but it doesn't work that way.

771
00:38:17.610 --> 00:38:20.380
That's absolutely patently wrong.

772
00:38:20.380 --> 00:38:25.125
So they break in, and they're looking for
evidence of something, right?

773
00:38:25.125 --> 00:38:26.522
They being law enforcement or whoever.

774
00:38:26.522 --> 00:38:28.926
And they'll sit down at the computer,
let me see what he did here.

775
00:38:28.926 --> 00:38:31.950
Look, he was out looking for
plans on the bridge.

776
00:38:31.950 --> 00:38:32.706
You have that kind of stuff.

777
00:38:32.706 --> 00:38:33.329
>> Right.

778
00:38:33.329 --> 00:38:35.646
>> I mean, just,
you cannot do that, right?

779
00:38:35.646 --> 00:38:38.327
>> [LAUGH]
>> You are not allowed to do that.

780
00:38:38.327 --> 00:38:40.594
You can say, look, there's a computer,

781
00:38:40.594 --> 00:38:42.935
let me make sure we put
an evidence tag on that.

782
00:38:42.935 --> 00:38:46.697
Stand somebody right next to with a gun,
do not allow anyone to touch this, and

783
00:38:46.697 --> 00:38:49.330
make sure it's powered on and
does not get turned off.

784
00:38:49.330 --> 00:38:52.203
But, you cannot go in there and
start hacking away at the system,

785
00:38:52.203 --> 00:38:54.203
look at its stuff,
until you have a warrant.

786
00:38:54.203 --> 00:38:57.414
Which is why, although you don't see
this on TV, but in the real world,

787
00:38:57.414 --> 00:38:59.900
you will see warrants show up
at the site after the fact.

788
00:38:59.900 --> 00:39:02.931
There's somebody who goes and
talks to the judge and says, okay, yeah.

789
00:39:02.931 --> 00:39:05.895
And then they show up, and they say,
okay, great, now we can go and

790
00:39:05.895 --> 00:39:06.800
we can do our stuff.

791
00:39:06.800 --> 00:39:12.020
But that thing sits until they have
the right to investigate this.

792
00:39:12.020 --> 00:39:14.345
So you could seize it, but
you cannot actually examine it.

793
00:39:14.345 --> 00:39:15.006
>> Very interesting.

794
00:39:15.006 --> 00:39:16.077
>> Very important to know.

795
00:39:16.077 --> 00:39:18.785
We've talked about things like
searches incident to a lawful arrest,

796
00:39:18.785 --> 00:39:21.280
inventory searches, border searches,
went through all this.

797
00:39:21.280 --> 00:39:24.164
I just wanted to show you one quick
thing that really deals with this.

798
00:39:24.164 --> 00:39:26.426
If you give me just a second here,
just as we're wrapping up,

799
00:39:26.426 --> 00:39:27.917
if you wanna join me here on the machine.

800
00:39:27.917 --> 00:39:32.406
The treaty that we are talking about here,
through the Council of Europe,

801
00:39:32.406 --> 00:39:37.125
is the Council of Europe's Cybercrime
Convention, completed in 2001.

802
00:39:37.125 --> 00:39:40.961
Obliges all signatories to have
the ability to affect cross-border

803
00:39:40.961 --> 00:39:42.424
preservation requests.

804
00:39:42.424 --> 00:39:45.535
Meaning, if government
A says to government B, hey,

805
00:39:45.535 --> 00:39:48.930
somebody fled our jurisdiction
with information we want.

806
00:39:48.930 --> 00:39:52.800
You need to act on our behalf and
to go get that and preserve it for us.

807
00:39:52.800 --> 00:39:55.207
If they're a signatory of this treaty,
that's how it happens.

808
00:39:55.207 --> 00:39:59.333
So the Council of Europe, and
in this case treaty number 185,

809
00:39:59.333 --> 00:40:03.030
the Convention on Cybercrime,
specific to cybercrime.

810
00:40:03.030 --> 00:40:06.437
Again, we're talking about forensic
investigation and digital data and

811
00:40:06.437 --> 00:40:07.742
preservation of said data.

812
00:40:07.742 --> 00:40:10.231
Is done internationally under
this particular treaty, so

813
00:40:10.231 --> 00:40:12.231
you just wanna make sure
you're aware of that.

814
00:40:12.231 --> 00:40:13.768
>> All right, consent and privacy,

815
00:40:13.768 --> 00:40:17.720
probably not the last time we're going to
hear those words come up in this series.

816
00:40:17.720 --> 00:40:20.893
But I'm looking at the clock, and
we're definitely going to have to keep

817
00:40:20.893 --> 00:40:23.979
rolling on with more parts to our
whole entire investigative process.

818
00:40:23.979 --> 00:40:27.430
A lot of fun learning how this is done,
methodologies behind it, and

819
00:40:27.430 --> 00:40:30.302
the things that we need to know so
that we do it correctly.

820
00:40:30.302 --> 00:40:34.090
And make sure all that evidence that
we've gathered is actually admissible and

821
00:40:34.090 --> 00:40:34.948
usable in court.

822
00:40:34.948 --> 00:40:38.550
That being said, I guess we're
out of time for this episode,

823
00:40:38.550 --> 00:40:40.292
thank you guys for watching.

824
00:40:40.292 --> 00:40:43.060
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

825
00:40:43.060 --> 00:40:44.549
>> I'm Adam Gordon.
>> And we'll see you next time.

826
00:40:44.549 --> 00:40:51.808
>> [MUSIC]

827
00:40:51.808 --> 00:40:54.285
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

that's right, we are coming back with more

>> All right, lets jump back in and

sort of investigative process.

25
00:00:56.164 --> 00:00:58.591
We've been going through
a lot of the legalities,

26
00:00:58.591 --> 00:01:02.093
and the definitions, and concerns
that investigators have to abide by,

27
00:01:02.093 --> 00:01:04.535
be aware of with regards to searching and
seizing.

28
00:01:04.535 --> 00:01:07.290
We just had a whole conversation about
what we can and cannot do with and

29
00:01:07.290 --> 00:01:08.093
without a warrant.

30
00:01:08.093 --> 00:01:09.665
If you haven't gone through and
looked at that.

31
00:01:09.665 --> 00:01:11.755
Maybe of interested to go back,

32
00:01:11.755 --> 00:01:14.105
It'll reference some of the stuff
we're about to get into with

33
00:01:14.105 --> 00:01:17.055
the Privacy Protection Act,
it's called PPA.

34
00:01:17.055 --> 00:01:19.685
Again, in the United States
under federal law,

35
00:01:19.685 --> 00:01:21.735
this is what we're talking about here.

36
00:01:21.735 --> 00:01:25.045
Want to always as we do, give you that
disclaimer, that we understand there

37
00:01:25.045 --> 00:01:29.085
are many, many areas of the world that are
not following this exact interpretation of

38
00:01:29.085 --> 00:01:32.870
a law, may call this by something
different or refer to it differently.

39
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:36.878
But from an exam perspective, aligning
with the exam requirements, and/or just

40
00:01:36.878 --> 00:01:40.785
from the knowledge perspective around,
how the material should be presented.

41
00:01:40.785 --> 00:01:45.178
We're doing this from
the US Federal Rules perspective and/or

42
00:01:45.178 --> 00:01:48.440
the US rules overall
with regards to evidence.

43
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:50.460
So, just making sure you're aware of that.

44
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:54.275
Not wanted to exclude or
include anybody unnecessarily.

45
00:01:54.275 --> 00:01:58.714
So the Privacy Protection Act is important
and lawful for a government officer to

46
00:01:58.714 --> 00:02:02.580
search for or seize materials when
certain requirements are not met.

47
00:02:02.580 --> 00:02:04.030
We should be aware of what they are.

48
00:02:04.030 --> 00:02:09.158
If the materials are the product or
work, meaning, you are doing something

49
00:02:09.158 --> 00:02:13.886
normally in the conduct of your
everyday job, we cannot search for and

50
00:02:13.886 --> 00:02:19.118
seize that material without a warrant,
because we don't have the right to.

51
00:02:19.118 --> 00:02:22.475
The materials include mental impressions,
conclusions or theories,

52
00:02:22.475 --> 00:02:26.436
and/or the materials are possessed for the
purpose of communicating the material to

53
00:02:26.436 --> 00:02:29.132
the public by a person some
form of public communication,

54
00:02:29.132 --> 00:02:31.040
according to the statute of law.

55
00:02:31.040 --> 00:02:31.960
In other words,

56
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:35.560
we cannot suppress the freedom of
speech with regards to searching and

57
00:02:35.560 --> 00:02:39.092
seizing evidence, because there is
not a justifiable reason to do so.

58
00:02:39.092 --> 00:02:42.431
We cannot come in and steal
the spreadsheet right off your machine and

59
00:02:42.431 --> 00:02:45.040
encumber this evidence
without a warrant to do so,

60
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:47.010
because it is the product of normal work.

61
00:02:47.010 --> 00:02:49.100
These are things that
we've to be aware of.

62
00:02:49.100 --> 00:02:52.670
And the language is broad in the PPA,
in the Privacy Protection Act, but

63
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:56.295
we do have to understand the privacy
rights our are forted individuals, and

64
00:02:56.295 --> 00:03:00.555
we have to be aware of and knowledgeable
of them as forensic investigators.

65
00:03:00.555 --> 00:03:02.625
The statute does contain exceptions,
however.

66
00:03:02.625 --> 00:03:05.405
So it's not okay, can't touch anything,
can't do anything.

67
00:03:05.405 --> 00:03:07.817
But rather,
we need to understand what we can do.

68
00:03:07.817 --> 00:03:09.127
So we just wanna be aware of that.

69
00:03:09.127 --> 00:03:12.961
Also, one of the big things that often
happens that people don't realize they

70
00:03:12.961 --> 00:03:16.622
have to deal with is, let's say
hypothetically, I have a situation where

71
00:03:16.622 --> 00:03:20.251
we have multiple locations that we want
to be able to search for evidence.

72
00:03:20.251 --> 00:03:25.368
Maybe we feel that a crime scene
is encompassed in many areas.

73
00:03:25.368 --> 00:03:28.807
And I talked about this in
the last episode where we said,

74
00:03:28.807 --> 00:03:33.251
either may be domicile home that has
two buildings on the plot of land, and

75
00:03:33.251 --> 00:03:35.558
each has a separate address, right?

76
00:03:35.558 --> 00:03:39.906
The mother-in-law quarters, whatever you
would call them in your part of the world.

77
00:03:39.906 --> 00:03:43.993
And as a result, or there's all these
different buildings in different

78
00:03:43.993 --> 00:03:48.348
geographies that make up the entity of
your company, abc.com but each one is

79
00:03:48.348 --> 00:03:52.971
gonna have its own separate address to
physically distinct from every other one,

80
00:03:52.971 --> 00:03:54.580
right, that kind of thing.

81
00:03:54.580 --> 00:03:57.665
And as a result of that,
it's considered its own separate entity.

82
00:03:57.665 --> 00:04:00.980
If you don't have a multiple,
let me try this again,

83
00:04:00.980 --> 00:04:04.780
if you have a multiple location scenario,
and don't have multiple warrants to cover

84
00:04:04.780 --> 00:04:07.460
those locations,
you are not able to legally search.

85
00:04:07.460 --> 00:04:10.471
So in other words, you can't use
one blanket warrant that says,

86
00:04:10.471 --> 00:04:12.608
we're gonna go search company abc.com, and

87
00:04:12.608 --> 00:04:16.331
find everything if you don't specify
what all the buildings, the properties,

88
00:04:16.331 --> 00:04:19.039
the addressable locations will be,
that doesn't work.

89
00:04:19.039 --> 00:04:22.442
So multiple locations, multiple
warrants very important to know that.

90
00:04:22.442 --> 00:04:26.480
And if we don't have those, the fruits of
that search are considered inadmissible.

91
00:04:26.480 --> 00:04:28.340
Very important to think
about that as well.

92
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:32.845
I'm here to seize, right,
your computers, right?

93
00:04:32.845 --> 00:04:35.375
Can we knock on the door and say,
hey, could you please let me in,

94
00:04:35.375 --> 00:04:37.745
I'm the law enforcement officer,
who's going to take you to jail.

95
00:04:37.745 --> 00:04:40.875
Please engage in that illegal
activity after you allow me in.

96
00:04:40.875 --> 00:04:43.635
Go back to what you were doing,
so I can arrest you, right?

97
00:04:43.635 --> 00:04:46.252
We don't do that clearly, right,
that just doesn't make any sense.

98
00:04:46.252 --> 00:04:50.102
In other words, are we suppose to announce
ourselves, right, and actually knock on

99
00:04:50.102 --> 00:04:52.512
the door and say, please stop what you
are doing, let me in and then resume.

100
00:04:52.512 --> 00:04:53.862
That's unreasonable.

101
00:04:53.862 --> 00:04:56.582
So we have what are called
no knock warrants, right?

102
00:04:56.582 --> 00:05:00.396
We have warrants that are issued by
a court that allow law enforcement

103
00:05:00.396 --> 00:05:04.802
officials to literally break down a door,
and jump into whatever is going on and

104
00:05:04.802 --> 00:05:05.940
arrest everybody.

105
00:05:05.940 --> 00:05:07.177
Assuming there is illegal or

106
00:05:07.177 --> 00:05:09.862
illicit activity without
announcing their presence first.

107
00:05:09.862 --> 00:05:12.893
Because, how many bad guys do you know
that are going to engage in that activity?

108
00:05:12.893 --> 00:05:15.371
>> [LAUGH]
>> After somebody knocks on the door and

109
00:05:15.371 --> 00:05:18.121
says, hey it's the police,
would you please allow us in so

110
00:05:18.121 --> 00:05:20.500
we could observe what you're doing, right?

111
00:05:20.500 --> 00:05:22.030
So we call these no knock warrants,

112
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:23.690
and you have to make sure
you're aware of that.

113
00:05:23.690 --> 00:05:26.000
Also we have what are called
delayed notice warrants.

114
00:05:26.000 --> 00:05:29.630
They allow us to surreptitiously observe,
we call is sneaking and peeking.

115
00:05:29.630 --> 00:05:30.502
Or sneaking and peeing,
as you certainly may have referred to.

116
00:05:30.502 --> 00:05:33.322
>> Yes, when you see the notes,
you would know.

117
00:05:33.322 --> 00:05:34.690
[LAUGH]
>> When you see the notes and

118
00:05:34.690 --> 00:05:36.434
the P-E-E is truncated from
the rest of that word.

119
00:05:36.434 --> 00:05:38.193
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it looks like sneaking peeing.

120
00:05:38.193 --> 00:05:40.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> So sneaking and peeking, right,

121
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:43.280
this is how a lot of
surveillance takes place.

122
00:05:43.280 --> 00:05:45.830
Where we have the ability to
watch somebody do something for

123
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:50.100

Multiply it by the number of
cylinders per disk, 18,121.

760
00:34:37.056 --> 00:34:40.697
The number of heads per cylinder,
so this number,

761
00:34:40.697 --> 00:34:45.114
multiplied by this number,
multiplied by 1 track per head.

762
00:34:45.114 --> 00:34:48.880
Again, no big deal there because we
don't have to worry about that, but

763
00:34:48.880 --> 00:34:52.270
just pointing that out,
times 43 sectors per track.

764
00:34:52.270 --> 00:34:56.980
Okay, so essentially, these three numbers
right here, multiplied together, okay?

765
00:34:56.980 --> 00:35:00.920
Cuz remember, multiplying by 1
doesn't change anything, right?

766
00:35:00.920 --> 00:35:01.985
2 times 1 is 2, right?

767
00:35:01.985 --> 00:35:05.166
[LAUGH] 1 times 1 is 1, that kind
of thing, right, it doesn't matter.

768
00:35:05.166 --> 00:35:07.270
It's not gonna change anything.

769
00:35:07.270 --> 00:35:14.750
So we're gonna multiply 18,121, 70, and 43
together times the number of bytes, 512.

770
00:35:14.750 --> 00:35:17.920
So really when you get a problem
like this, you just have to take all

771
00:35:17.920 --> 00:35:21.110
the numbers in the problem,
right, that are not one, right?

772
00:35:21.110 --> 00:35:23.820
And multiply them together,
that's the secret.

773
00:35:23.820 --> 00:35:28.692
And when you do all that,
if you were to do the math, you would get,

774
00:35:28.692 --> 00:35:32.520
in this particular case with
the numbers I gave you,

775
00:35:32.520 --> 00:35:35.751
you would get this amount of bytes, right?

776
00:35:35.751 --> 00:35:39.071
27,926,635,520, or roughly, what,
about almost 28 gigabytes, right, give or

777
00:35:39.071 --> 00:35:39.790
take just about.

778
00:35:39.790 --> 00:35:42.040
If you round up,
about 28 gigabytes, right?

779
00:35:42.040 --> 00:35:45.790
So we can see that if we were
given this word problem,

780
00:35:45.790 --> 00:35:49.600
in theory, although obviously numbers
would most likely be different.

781
00:35:49.600 --> 00:35:53.770
But if we were given a word problem like
this and had to then figure this out,

782
00:35:53.770 --> 00:35:57.020
we would have to extract the number of
cylinders, heads, sectors per track, and

783
00:35:57.020 --> 00:36:01.810

gonna be an extended value in bytes.

784
00:36:01.810 --> 00:36:04.470
And remember, we then have to do
the calculation if we're asked,

785
00:36:04.470 --> 00:36:05.640
okay, not in bytes.

786
00:36:05.640 --> 00:36:09.770

787
00:36:09.770 --> 00:36:13.070
You would just have to convert and
make sure you take that number and

788
00:36:13.070 --> 00:36:15.810

789
00:36:15.810 --> 00:36:17.422
But that is how you would
do the calculation, right?

790

37

50

75

77

78
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:16.020

layout of the disc volume.

79
00:03:16.020 --> 00:03:18.428

80
00:03:18.428 --> 00:03:20.398
where we will find things and
how to access it.

81
00:03:20.398 --> 00:03:25.750
The volume partition on partition devices

82
00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:29.080
Whereas the unpartitioned devices,

83
00:03:29.080 --> 00:03:31.260
In other words, in an unpartitioned disk,

84
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:36.490
that bios parameters block describes
the size of the entire drive overall.

85
00:03:36.490 --> 00:03:39.720
This physicality of the entire
space that's available.

86
00:03:39.720 --> 00:03:42.270
When we partition it,
it describes the subset,

87
00:03:42.270 --> 00:03:44.480
the allocated amount that
has been partitioned and

88
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:47.470
it tells us how to read that volume,

89
00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:51.610
If you're dual booting your system, you

90
00:03:51.610 --> 00:03:52.480
different partitions,

91
00:03:52.480 --> 00:03:56.170

00:03:56.170 --> 00:03:59.320

93

98
00:04:12.790 --> 00:04:17.162

of floppy disks and having to fix the MBR

99
00:04:17.162 --> 00:04:21.485
to reset and reallocate the partitioning
so that way we could reinstall an OS.

100
00:04:21.485 --> 00:04:25.562
And change the actual allocation of space
on the drive without getting an error

101
00:04:25.562 --> 00:04:29.515
because you would get about halfway
through, I'm thinking like MT4 way,

102
00:04:29.515 --> 00:04:30.890
way back in the past.

103
00:04:30.890 --> 00:04:34.600
If you would reinstall MT4 on top
of an existing installation and

104
00:04:34.600 --> 00:04:38.450
you use the same size partition and
not modified in any way, you would get

105
00:04:38.450 --> 00:04:42.235
an error about half way through when you
go to read and start installing the MBR.

106
00:04:42.235 --> 00:04:44.610
Would say, wait,
this is supposed to be this and here and

107
00:04:44.610 --> 00:04:46.680
it's not there anymore and
it would just die.

108
00:04:46.680 --> 00:04:49.850
And it would not let you install it
because you had to reset the MBR,

109
00:04:49.850 --> 00:04:51.200
wipe it clean.

110
00:04:51.200 --> 00:04:53.870
In other words, reallocate space and
tell it how to find it.

111
00:04:53.870 --> 00:04:57.080
And so the trick was, you'd have to
change the size of the partition,

112
00:04:57.080 --> 00:05:00.350
forcing an entry into the MBR that
would then allow you install.

113
00:05:00.350 --> 00:05:01.850
This was the old school
way of doing things.

114
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:04.030
The new school way is you get
the Geek Squad to come and

115
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:04.981
take care all that for you.

116
00:05:04.981 --> 00:05:06.128
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't even have to worry about

117
00:05:06.128 --> 00:05:06.708
that anymore, right?

118
00:05:06.708 --> 00:05:08.382
Just call for help, right?

119
00:05:08.382 --> 00:05:11.123
So the MBR is the first sector,
what's called sector zero,

120
00:05:11.123 --> 00:05:14.805
don't confuse this with the bios parameter
block remember that's sector one.

121
00:05:14.805 --> 00:05:18.250
When we say first sector,

122
00:05:18.250 --> 00:05:21.577
So when we say first sector,

123
00:05:21.577 --> 00:05:25.125
BIOS parameter block sector one,
second sector overall even though

124
00:05:25.125 --> 00:05:29.220
it is called sector one it's the overall
second sector on the hard drive.

125
00:05:29.220 --> 00:05:31.750
Important to keep that in mind to
keep that straight otherwise you're

126
00:05:31.750 --> 00:05:33.160
gonna mix up your zeroes and ones.

127
00:05:33.160 --> 00:05:34.750
And well then you're gonna have twos and
threes.

128
00:05:34.750 --> 00:05:38.490
>> It's super easy for us to do because
we are used to starting with one.

129
00:05:38.490 --> 00:05:40.150
>> We are
>> That's the first way,

130
00:05:40.150 --> 00:05:42.620
you will hose yourself more times

131
00:05:42.620 --> 00:05:45.900
no pun intended, when it comes to doing
that cuz I've done it plenty of time I'm

132
00:05:45.900 --> 00:05:47.080
sure you have as well
>> Yeah,

133
00:05:47.080 --> 00:05:49.100
just a standing rule of thumb that,
you know,

134
00:05:49.100 --> 00:05:52.580
just remember anything with a computer
I tell my students this all the time.

135
00:05:52.580 --> 00:05:55.050
Everything, without, exception,
you start numbering from zero.

136
00:05:55.050 --> 00:05:58.005
Right, just so you know,
you gotta account for that extra one,

137
00:05:58.005 --> 00:06:00.485
because it's always gonna
be zero as opposed to one.

138
00:06:00.485 --> 00:06:01.650
So just be aware of that.

139
00:06:01.650 --> 00:06:03.980
All right, so just master boot record,
there are gonna be sector zero.

140
00:06:03.980 --> 00:06:07.790
First sector of data storage device
on the hard drive traditionally.

141
00:06:07.790 --> 00:06:10.800
Information there regarding
the files on the disk, location,

142
00:06:10.800 --> 00:06:15.020
size, important data, overall just
about how we access data on the drive

143
00:06:15.020 --> 00:06:16.750
is stored in the master boot record.

144
00:06:16.750 --> 00:06:20.080
You wanna screw up somebody's day, go and
mess around with the master boot record.

145
00:06:20.080 --> 00:06:23.110
That's a sure fire way to allow
them not to be able to get in.

146
00:06:23.110 --> 00:06:26.530
But we can go in, and we can
certainly fix the master boot record.

We can back it up, we can restore it.

148

just a minute using DD and Linux Unix.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk through the common methodologies and tools used in retrieving data and duplicating that data for the purposes of investigation. 611
00:27:36.900 --> 00:27:39.380
So a lot of times when we
have web hosting involved,

612
00:27:39.380 --> 00:27:41.240
we often see cross-platform correlation.

613
00:27:41.240 --> 00:27:44.600
The majority of web hosting today
is done on non-Windows platforms.

614
00:27:44.600 --> 00:27:49.639
When we have virtualization involved, we
often see cross-platform because a lot of

615
00:27:50.700 --> 00:27:56.170
host virtualization systems may be
running VMware, may be running Citrix,

616
00:27:56.170 --> 00:28:01.588
the Zen platform, the ESXi or
vSphere platform, are Linux Unix based.

617
00:28:01.588 --> 00:28:06.680
Whereas the Hyper-V platform, the third
major provider of virtualization services,

618
00:28:06.680 --> 00:28:08.790
Microsoft, is Windows based, right?

619
00:28:08.790 --> 00:28:12.340
So we're gonna see cross-platform
collaboration, communication,

620
00:28:12.340 --> 00:28:15.140
and therefore event correlation
just between hosts and

621
00:28:15.140 --> 00:28:18.730
VMs running on them because the guest
operating systems are gonna be often

622
00:28:18.730 --> 00:28:21.230
based on a different OS
than the hosting is.

623
00:28:21.230 --> 00:28:24.780
So we have to think about that and just
understand the logic of how we go back and

624
00:28:24.780 --> 00:28:26.050
forth and compare the two.

625
00:28:26.050 --> 00:28:28.380
Because with a network
forensics thought process,

626
00:28:28.380 --> 00:28:31.760
we're looking at traffic flows often
from guest OSs in the virtual and

627
00:28:31.760 --> 00:28:35.750
Cloud world, out through a host and
out onto a network and back again.

628
00:28:35.750 --> 00:28:38.200
We have to account for
every stop along the way.

629
00:28:38.200 --> 00:28:41.266
The configuration of the virtual switches,
for instance,

630
00:28:41.266 --> 00:28:45.247
in the host, the configuration of the
virtual network cards in the guest OSs.

631
00:28:45.247 --> 00:28:48.300
Or when I say guest OSs I mean
virtual machines generically.

632
00:28:48.300 --> 00:28:50.830
We just call them guest OSs traditionally.

633
00:28:50.830 --> 00:28:53.220
But in the virtual machine,
the settings there.

634
00:28:53.220 --> 00:28:57.300
Versus the configuration on the host that
allows those networks to be propagated and

635
00:28:57.300 --> 00:28:59.770
passed out into the physical world.

636
00:28:59.770 --> 00:29:02.950
The network settings in the data center
and beyond, are they software defined or

637
00:29:02.950 --> 00:29:04.290
are they manually applied?

638
00:29:04.290 --> 00:29:07.500
There's all these things we'd have to
think about as forensic investigators

639
00:29:07.500 --> 00:29:09.660
to help us understand that traffic flow.

640
00:29:09.660 --> 00:29:13.413
And that's more complicated in a virtual
and Cloud world today than it would be in

641
00:29:13.413 --> 00:29:17.500
a non-Cloud, a non-virtual world today
where we're dealing with physical entities

642
00:29:17.500 --> 00:29:20.400
and just configuration of
those network setting there.

643
00:29:20.400 --> 00:29:21.810
We're extracting, in other words,

644
00:29:21.810 --> 00:29:26.090
and extrapolating additional layers
of complexity when we virtualize, and

645
00:29:26.090 --> 00:29:28.620
we have to account for
those as forensic investigators.

646
00:29:28.620 --> 00:29:31.400
So it is one of those areas that
can be very interesting, but

647
00:29:31.400 --> 00:29:33.580
also incredibly complex to work with.

648
00:29:33.580 --> 00:29:37.060
If you have software defined networking,
and software defined storage, and

649
00:29:37.060 --> 00:29:39.640
software defined data centers all up and
down the stack,

650
00:29:39.640 --> 00:29:44.180
there is a lot of additional work as
forensic investigators we have to do.

651
00:29:44.180 --> 00:29:46.890
Because we have to look at all
the configurations that are applied, and

652
00:29:46.890 --> 00:29:49.660
were they standardized,
continuous monitoring has to be in place.

653
00:29:49.660 --> 00:29:52.010
We have to pull those log files and
look at whether or

654
00:29:52.010 --> 00:29:55.760
not there was deviation from those
baselines and those applied settings.

655
00:29:55.760 --> 00:29:57.850
And if so, under what conditions and why?

656
00:29:57.850 --> 00:30:00.600
And was there remediation,
and if so, at what point?

657
00:30:00.600 --> 00:30:05.080
And did the attack occur during the gap,
the delta, between noncompliance and

658
00:30:05.080 --> 00:30:06.000
remediation?

659
00:30:06.000 --> 00:30:06.940
Was that by accident?

660
00:30:06.940 --> 00:30:08.120
Was it on purpose?

661
00:30:08.120 --> 00:30:10.980
Was somebody in a position that
was able to manipulate that,

662
00:30:10.980 --> 00:30:13.790
taking advantage of those settings and
working between them?

663
00:30:13.790 --> 00:30:17.720
There's all these things that can add to
the complexity in Cloud and virtualized

664
00:30:17.720 --> 00:30:21.420
environments that we just don't deal with
in traditional environments normally.

665
00:30:21.420 --> 00:30:24.637
I'm not saying there isn't software
defining that goes on in non-Cloud,

666
00:30:24.637 --> 00:30:25.900
non-virtualized environments.

667
00:30:25.900 --> 00:30:28.960
And I'm not saying we don't
have high levels of automation.

668
00:30:28.960 --> 00:30:32.866
All that stuff exists, but it may not be
as complex as it would be if we add Cloud

669
00:30:32.866 --> 00:30:35.772
and virtualization of the mix,
is all I'm suggesting.

670
00:30:35.772 --> 00:30:39.846
And as a result, we have to worry
about that and take that into account.

671
00:30:39.846 --> 00:30:43.260
Cloud-based forensics, and
virtualization-based forensics

672
00:30:43.260 --> 00:30:47.030
is a whole separate area today that
requires additional knowledge and

673
00:30:47.030 --> 00:30:49.250
additional skill sets to execute properly.

674
00:30:49.250 --> 00:30:52.170
Much, much more involved
traditionally than what we talk about

675
00:30:52.170 --> 00:30:55.020
often just in the scope of
our conversations here.

676
00:30:55.020 --> 00:30:56.040
And a very interesting one, right?

677
00:30:56.040 --> 00:30:59.220
We spend a lot working in those areas,
but a very difficult one,

678
00:30:59.220 --> 00:31:00.570
a lot of challenges there.

679
00:31:00.570 --> 00:31:01.170
>> That’s right.

680
00:31:01.170 --> 00:31:03.065
Obviously, this is one,
I’m having a lot of fun,

681
00:31:03.065 --> 00:31:04.580
hopefully you’re having a lot of fun.

682
00:31:04.580 --> 00:31:07.480
And we're just getting warmed up,
a lot of good conversation going on here.

683
00:31:07.480 --> 00:31:11.950
But unfortunately, our clock is telling us
that we have to do yet another episode.

684
00:31:11.950 --> 00:31:14.060
So poor us.
[LAUGH] But hopefully,

685
00:31:14.060 --> 00:31:15.840
you guys will join us back for that one.

686
00:31:15.840 --> 00:31:17.945
As for this, I guess it is time for
us to sign off.

687
00:31:17.945 --> 00:31:19.120
Thanks for watching.

688
00:31:19.120 --> 00:31:21.750
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

689
00:31:21.750 --> 00:31:22.940
>> I am, who am I?

690
00:31:22.940 --> 00:31:24.720
I'm Adam Gordon, that's who I am.

691
00:31:24.720 --> 00:31:27.720
>> And he's gonna figure out who he is and
we'll see you next time.

692
00:31:27.720 --> 00:31:30.288
>> Take care everybody.

693
00:31:30.288 --> 00:31:35.893
[MUSIC]

694
00:31:35.893 --> 00:31:38.829
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore network forensics from a CHFI perspective. Here they will look over some foundational networking concepts as well as key areas of networking that a CHFI would need to be aware of to be effective. Specific topic here include: Correlation approaches, the importance of NTP, log management systems, and logging in Linux, Windows, Syslog, and IIS.
episodes.title: Network Forensics Part 3

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:01.525
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.525 --> 00:00:06.262
I'm your host, Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3

4
