5
00:00:12.126 --> 00:00:14.047
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:14.047 --> 00:00:16.660
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.660 --> 00:00:18.782
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.782 --> 00:00:23.470
in today's episode we are continuing
in our CHFR Version 9 series.

9
00:00:23.470 --> 00:00:26.760
And of course, joining us back in
the studio to continue our conversation

10
00:00:26.760 --> 00:00:30.690
on network forensics, the forensic man
himself, our good friend, Mr. Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:31.570
Adam, welcome back, man.

12
00:00:31.570 --> 00:00:32.400
How's it going?

13
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:33.760
>> Good, good.
Hopefully going well for all of you.

14
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:35.780
Gonna continue our conversations.

15
00:00:35.780 --> 00:00:37.280
Part three, as they say.

16
00:00:37.280 --> 00:00:39.401
Because part two, well,
just wasn't good enough.

17
00:00:39.401 --> 00:00:41.127
>> [LAUGH]
>> We had more stuff to talk about.

18
00:00:41.127 --> 00:00:42.295
So, we're gonna jump back in.

19
00:00:42.295 --> 00:00:45.740
We left off talking about correlation and
the approaches to correlation.

20
00:00:45.740 --> 00:00:49.680
Event correlation is the idea of
taking events along a timeline and

21
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:52.510
relating them in some way to things
that we're looking to investigate or

22
00:00:52.510 --> 00:00:54.160
prove may or may not have happened.

23
00:00:54.160 --> 00:00:58.400
So we lay down the thought process around
defining event correlation at the very end

24
00:00:58.400 --> 00:00:59.700
of our last episode.

25
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:01.740
But we do wanna take a look
at different approaches.

26
00:01:01.740 --> 00:01:04.860
There are many different correlation
approaches that can be used, so

27
00:01:04.860 --> 00:01:06.418
I thought we'd share a list with you.

28
00:01:06.418 --> 00:01:09.130
If you wanna throw the list up here for
me, we'll take a look.

29
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:13.667
So you can see here, we have graph-based,
neural network-based, codebook-based,

30
00:01:13.667 --> 00:01:14.930
rule-based, etc.

31
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:18.110
We'll just go through quickly and talk
about the definitions among them here and

32
00:01:18.110 --> 00:01:19.930
just make sure we understand the logic.

33
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:21.010
I would say that

34
00:01:22.260 --> 00:01:25.230
probably wanna be thinking about
these in two-fold, two ways.

35
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:27.990
Number one, certainly,
with regards to exam perpetration.

36
00:01:27.990 --> 00:01:31.460
You never know when you may get asked
about different correlation approaches.

37
00:01:31.460 --> 00:01:35.130
Perhaps have to grab them out of a list,
mix and match, drag and drop.

38
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:38.810
You may have to define
a correlation approach based on its

39
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:42.490
use in a word problem to solve,
or to identify.

40
00:01:42.490 --> 00:01:45.380
So there's lot of ways I could
see being asked about this.

41
00:01:45.380 --> 00:01:48.630
Also obviously, in the real world,
as you apply this knowledge,

42
00:01:48.630 --> 00:01:51.370
important to know that different
tools that you may use.

43
00:01:51.370 --> 00:01:55.190
Log management programs, for instance,
may use correlation approaches or

44
00:01:55.190 --> 00:01:58.620
correlation engines, and
you wanna be aware of those approaches.

45
00:01:58.620 --> 00:01:59.670
So graph-based.

46
00:01:59.670 --> 00:02:02.520
We graph out each node as a component.

47
00:02:02.520 --> 00:02:05.625
And we kind of look at the dependencies
among and between them so

48
00:02:05.625 --> 00:02:09.258
we can look at visual mapping and
representation of how systems connect to

49
00:02:09.258 --> 00:02:12.250
each other as a graph-based
correlation approach.

50
00:02:12.250 --> 00:02:13.460
Neural network-based.

51
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:17.230
We use neural networks to detect
anomalies, root cause failures,

52
00:02:17.230 --> 00:02:18.280
things like that.

53
00:02:18.280 --> 00:02:21.840
So we're looking at
the actual data stream and

54
00:02:21.840 --> 00:02:26.800
looking at the ways in which we may
find anomalies based on those things.

55
00:02:26.800 --> 00:02:31.380
Any of these modern data
aggregation engines, SEM systems,

56
00:02:31.380 --> 00:02:35.870
things of that nature, would use
correlation approaches to examine data,

57
00:02:35.870 --> 00:02:39.320
looking for patterns that may not
seem obvious on the surface as well.

58
00:02:39.320 --> 00:02:42.110
So you see this in a lot of
different technology today,

59
00:02:42.110 --> 00:02:45.540
not just necessarily in network forensics.

60
00:02:45.540 --> 00:02:47.985
But any kind of a SEM system
would use this approach as well.

61
00:02:47.985 --> 00:02:49.130
Codebook-based.

62
00:02:49.130 --> 00:02:51.760
We use codebooks to store sets
of events and correlate them.

63
00:02:51.760 --> 00:02:54.400
Think of that as almost being
like an extended log where

64
00:02:54.400 --> 00:02:59.340
we have lots of different references,
or information in different buckets, and

65
00:02:59.340 --> 00:03:03.135
we can then correlate between them based
on filtering and things of that nature.

66
00:03:03.135 --> 00:03:03.992
Rule-based.

67
00:03:03.992 --> 00:03:07.846
Let me just scroll down here so
we can see these.

68
00:03:07.846 --> 00:03:10.442
Bring up the, did I go past rule?

69
00:03:10.442 --> 00:03:11.345
Yes, I did.

70
00:03:11.345 --> 00:03:12.696
There we go.

71
00:03:12.696 --> 00:03:13.576
Went one too far.

72
00:03:13.576 --> 00:03:14.638
So rule-based, right?

73
00:03:14.638 --> 00:03:16.560
This is almost like a firewall, right?

74
00:03:16.560 --> 00:03:19.760
Does filtering, we're looking at
condition action based on rules.

75
00:03:19.760 --> 00:03:22.109
Does this information match this criteria,
yes or no?

76
00:03:22.109 --> 00:03:24.588
If it does, put it over here on the right,
under positive.

77
00:03:24.588 --> 00:03:26.590
If not, ignore it, and put it on the left.

78
00:03:26.590 --> 00:03:27.660
That kind of thing.

79
00:03:27.660 --> 00:03:30.910
So we're looking at just different
ways we can actualize, or

80
00:03:30.910 --> 00:03:34.576
different ways that these
activities may actually occur.

81
00:03:34.576 --> 00:03:35.642
Field-Based.

82
00:03:35.642 --> 00:03:39.125
Specific events are compared within single
or multiple fields of the normalized data.

83
00:03:39.125 --> 00:03:41.235
Think of this as almost
like a string search.

84
00:03:41.235 --> 00:03:46.195
We're looking for specific items,
perhaps a term or perhaps pieces of

85
00:03:46.195 --> 00:03:49.865
information that may have been entered,
and we're gonna correlate based on that.

86
00:03:51.180 --> 00:03:53.430
Automated field correlation.

87
00:03:53.430 --> 00:03:56.390
Checks and compares all fields
systematically, looking at positive and

88
00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:58.020
negative matches.

89
00:03:58.020 --> 00:04:00.180
So we can correlate
across multiple fields.

90
00:04:00.180 --> 00:04:03.660
This is just going to be an additional

91
00:04:03.660 --> 00:04:07.280
capability associated with
our field based up above.

92
00:04:07.280 --> 00:04:10.180
We just automate the process
with some sort of filters or

93
00:04:10.180 --> 00:04:14.090
search parameters that we may indicate or
input as we get started, and

94
00:04:14.090 --> 00:04:16.840
let the computer essentially
do the work for us.

95
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:20.270
Because it's gonna be quicker
obviously and much more focus on that.

96
00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:25.010
We do have pocket parameter and
or payload correlation.

97
00:04:25.010 --> 00:04:28.650
We use this to look to particular
packets in relation to others.

98
00:04:28.650 --> 00:04:33.320
So we make a list of packets that seem
suspicious or perhaps are interesting

99
00:04:33.320 --> 00:04:38.500
based on some sort of variable or some
sort of parameter we may want to find.

100
00:04:38.500 --> 00:04:42.020
Show me all Apple packets.

101
00:04:42.020 --> 00:04:46.109
Show me all SPX/IPX packets.

102
00:04:46.109 --> 00:04:47.570
All Novell traffic.

103
00:04:47.570 --> 00:04:50.200
Show me all streaming media packets.

104
00:04:50.200 --> 00:04:54.827
You'll revalidate and or verify different
packet traces based on parameters and or

105
00:04:54.827 --> 00:04:57.905
traffic flow, and
then we're gonna correlate those.

106
00:04:57.905 --> 00:05:02.600
We may be looking to understand and
identify new attack vectors.

107
00:05:02.600 --> 00:05:06.590
And as a result, we may be looking
at current known attack signatures.

108
00:05:06.590 --> 00:05:10.831
Think of how Anti-Malware software works,
how firewalls work where we have rules, or

109
00:05:10.831 --> 00:05:12.907
signature files we will compare against.

110
00:05:12.907 --> 00:05:14.247
And payload correlation or

111
00:05:14.247 --> 00:05:17.108
packet parameter correlation
will work similar to that.

112
00:05:17.108 --> 00:05:21.243
So we'll profile or finger print based,
where we gather evidence and

113
00:05:21.243 --> 00:05:24.817
look at attack profiles that may
have already been created or

114
00:05:24.817 --> 00:05:26.865
are going to be loaded into a tool.

115
00:05:26.865 --> 00:05:30.735
A lot of times you'll get these more
advanced tools that come with a whole set

116
00:05:30.735 --> 00:05:34.845
of these precompiled filters based
on prior activity that the vendor

117
00:05:34.845 --> 00:05:39.195
has correlated across thousands, tens,
hundreds of thousands of events.

118
00:05:39.195 --> 00:05:41.765
And you'll be able to see all those and
understand those, right?

119
00:05:41.765 --> 00:05:44.129
So we're getting the benefit of those.

120
00:05:44.129 --> 00:05:47.682
Vulnerability based, IDS, IPS traffic and

121
00:05:47.682 --> 00:05:51.430
events can be used to
manifest attack vectors.

122
00:05:51.430 --> 00:05:54.360
And so we'll be looking for
known vulnerabilities, may be

123
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:58.450
able to predict attacks based on the
weakness or vulnerability that is there.

124
00:05:58.450 --> 00:06:02.970
So we may scan a system, see there's
an unpatched hold that we have to address.

125
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:05.090
And if we don't, we know they we're
probably vulnerable to certain

126
00:06:05.090 --> 00:06:05.735
kinds of traffic.

127
00:06:05.735 --> 00:06:07.780
Open-port.

128
00:06:07.780 --> 00:06:08.678
Speaks for itself.

129
00:06:08.678 --> 00:06:10.460
We're looking at ports that are open,

130
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:14.840
knowing certain ports may allow certain
traffic to occur and or to flow.

131
00:06:14.840 --> 00:06:17.410
What's the value of knowing
those ports are open?

132
00:06:17.410 --> 00:06:20.650
What kind of attacks are we going to
be subjected to as a result of that?

133
00:06:20.650 --> 00:06:22.470
That's the kinda thing
we'd want to know about.

134
00:06:22.470 --> 00:06:24.170
Bayesian correlation.

135
00:06:24.170 --> 00:06:29.050
This is where we look at, and
we essentially predict or

136
00:06:29.050 --> 00:06:33.150
attempt to predict what may happen
based on statistics and probability.

137
00:06:33.150 --> 00:06:35.145
It's more of a mathematical approach.

138
00:06:35.145 --> 00:06:39.085
We're looking at the incidence of certain
activities and extrapolating those, and

139
00:06:39.085 --> 00:06:45.825
saying based on prior traffic flows,
current traffic patterns, we can say we

140
00:06:45.825 --> 00:06:51.335
often see this kind of behavior recurring
every 10,000 packets, or every 30 minutes.

141
00:06:51.335 --> 00:06:55.105
Or whatever the time value or
data flow rate may be.

142
00:06:55.105 --> 00:06:58.640
And so we think we'll see this kind
of activity within the next two hours

143
00:06:58.640 --> 00:07:00.440
based on a normal flow.

144
00:07:00.440 --> 00:07:03.270
We can then begin to understand and
essentially zero in on,

145
00:07:03.270 --> 00:07:06.610
the kind of activity that may
occur based on timing, or

146
00:07:06.610 --> 00:07:09.870
values associated with timing and
traffic flow.

147
00:07:09.870 --> 00:07:11.427

knowledge of the system owners and/or
the controllers along the way.

601
00:29:36.255 --> 00:29:38.375
And if we can validate that,
we can present that,

602
00:29:38.375 --> 00:29:40.570
as we talked about under
the federal rules of evidence.

603
00:29:40.570 --> 00:29:44.880
Remember rule 803, if that's in question,
chances are good that data may not be

604
00:29:44.880 --> 00:29:48.490
allowed to be presented in a case or
in a court of law.

605
00:29:48.490 --> 00:29:52.830
That doesn't mean we can't use it for
outside of the courtroom for

606
00:29:52.830 --> 00:29:55.510
investigations that may
not end in a trial.

607
00:29:55.510 --> 00:29:57.900
But it means that we would not be able
to legally present that evidence in

608
00:29:57.900 --> 00:29:58.880
a court of law.

609
00:29:58.880 --> 00:30:01.200
So remember administrative events or

610
00:30:01.200 --> 00:30:03.730
administrative investigations
that occur inside the company

611
00:30:03.730 --> 00:30:07.560
that may not go into a court may have very
different standards for burdens of proof.

612
00:30:07.560 --> 00:30:10.340
Because we don't have to validate
the data at the same level.

613
00:30:10.340 --> 00:30:12.590
It doesn't mean we just simply
walk away from data validation and

614
00:30:12.590 --> 00:30:14.430
say, well best effort, I think it's okay.

615
00:30:14.430 --> 00:30:17.060
But you know there's all this evidence
of somebody tampering over here but

616
00:30:17.060 --> 00:30:18.290
we're not gonna worry about that.

617
00:30:18.290 --> 00:30:21.990
We have to make that clear to the client
but the bar, the burden of proof, may or

618
00:30:21.990 --> 00:30:23.050
may not be at the same level.

619
00:30:23.050 --> 00:30:25.350
It really depends on the nature
of the circumstances and

620
00:30:25.350 --> 00:30:28.710
the investigation that's taking place so
just keep that in mind as well.

621
00:30:28.710 --> 00:30:31.000
>> That's right.
Logging is an extremely important aspect

622
00:30:31.000 --> 00:30:33.180
of our jobs not as just sys devices.

623
00:30:33.180 --> 00:30:36.730
Anybody inside of IT in general we've
got to turn on the logging systems so

624
00:30:36.730 --> 00:30:38.630
that we can see the events
that have occurred.

625
00:30:38.630 --> 00:30:43.460
And then it's up to us as CHFI to
interpret that data, be able to find

626
00:30:43.460 --> 00:30:47.480
maybe the fact that there has been an
incident that has occurred and used that.

627
00:30:47.480 --> 00:30:50.980
And then present that and keep the
integrity of the data so that you can take

628
00:30:50.980 --> 00:30:55.710
it court if necessary or just to present
it to someone that's hired you for, maybe,

629
00:30:55.710 --> 00:30:59.240
firing purposes or corrective
measures as they need to take them.

630
00:30:59.240 --> 00:31:00.660
That being said.

631
00:31:00.660 --> 00:31:03.600
Importance of logging can't be
understated or can't be overstated,

632
00:31:03.600 --> 00:31:05.219
should I say- Because-
>> It can be understated.

633
00:31:05.219 --> 00:31:06.360
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it can be understated.

634
00:31:06.360 --> 00:31:07.050
It can't be overstated.

635
00:31:07.050 --> 00:31:07.820
>> It can't be overstated.

636
00:31:07.820 --> 00:31:10.270
>> Because we're getting ready to do
a whole nother episode, more on logging.

637
00:31:10.270 --> 00:31:11.890
So, come back for that next episode.

638
00:31:11.890 --> 00:31:12.780
It's gonna be great.

639
00:31:12.780 --> 00:31:14.510
It is important stuff for us to know.

640
00:31:14.510 --> 00:31:16.210
That being said, it is time for
us to sign off for

641
00:31:16.210 --> 00:31:19.600
this episode For ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

642
00:31:19.600 --> 00:31:20.750
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

643
00:31:20.750 --> 00:31:21.640
>> And we'll see you next time.

644
00:31:28.810 --> 00:31:31.270
Thank you for watching IT PRO TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore network forensics from a CHFI perspective. Here they will look over some foundational networking concepts as well as key areas of networking that a CHFI would need to be aware of to be effective. Specific topic here include: Analyzing router logs, logs for Cisco and Juniper, IDS/IPS logs, Honeyepot logs, and Fundamentals of reconstruction of a crime.

00:04:20.772 --> 00:04:21.290
>> [LAUGH]
>> Third-party

rounding of routing

the fact that if we do hand off

00:04:46.567 --> 00:04:50.906
traditionally In incoming logs, we tend

00:04:50.906 --> 00:04:54.740
outgoing logs tend to represent

104
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:58.320
That doesn't mean that we can't find

00:05:07.075 --> 00:05:10.553
no special kind of router, normal logging,
no special kind of logging,

00:05:10.553 --> 00:05:13.373
just out of the box,

00:05:13.373 --> 00:05:15.570

00:05:15.570 --> 00:05:17.000
So keeping that in mind and

making sure aware that we are thinking

114
00:05:26.270 --> 00:05:29.060
We have to think about whether or

116
00:05:33.120 --> 00:05:34.880
Something has or has not happened.

00:05:34.880 --> 00:05:39.330
For instance, outgoing log details
where we may get URL information and

ports, right, will be important.

119
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:44.120
You see we do have ports in both places,
both incoming and outgoing.

120
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:44.780
Not unusual.

121
00:05:44.780 --> 00:05:48.810
But we may not see, for incoming we're
not gonna see the URL information.

122
00:05:48.810 --> 00:05:50.280
We'll see IP addresses coming back and

123
00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:53.500
forth and the ability to
correlate that would be important.

124
00:05:53.500 --> 00:05:56.480
Because we wanna know that IP
address equals that web server.

125
00:05:56.480 --> 00:05:58.360
You know, in theory maybe if
that's what we're looking at.

126
00:05:58.360 --> 00:06:00.280
And we have to understand that traffic.

127
00:06:00.280 --> 00:06:03.843
And so, it would be helpful for us to

128
00:06:03.843 --> 00:06:06.550
And something for us to think about and
be concerned with.

129
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:07.790
I have a note there at the bottom.

130
00:06:07.790 --> 00:06:09.170
Your R cache is important.

131
00:06:09.170 --> 00:06:12.160
R minus eight to remind us of the fact,
as we've shown you and

132
00:06:12.160 --> 00:06:14.790
talked about many times already,
that there are lots and

133
00:06:14.790 --> 00:06:18.350
lots of pieces to the puzzle of
putting together the transmission,

134
00:06:18.350 --> 00:06:22.050
the reception of data and looking
at it from multiple vantage points.

135
00:06:22.050 --> 00:06:25.680
Sender, the recipient,
the hop count, how many devices or

136
00:06:25.680 --> 00:06:28.590

what do those gateways or

137
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:32.520
devices tell us about the information,
its status as it moved through there,

138
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:35.370
was integrity ensured all the way
through the transmission path.

139
00:06:35.370 --> 00:06:36.580
Was the integrity modified?

140
00:06:36.580 --> 00:06:37.620
If so, where?

141
00:06:37.620 --> 00:06:38.790
Can we zero that in?

142
00:06:38.790 --> 00:06:41.130
These are things we have to know about.

143
00:06:41.130 --> 00:06:43.850
Not that the R cache by itself
will tell us all of that.

144
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:46.660
Quite the opposite tells us
none of that for the most part.

145
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:51.140
But it does tell us the MAC address,
IP mapping on the client in question.

146
00:06:51.140 --> 00:06:52.820
Whatever endpoint we're looking at.

147
00:06:52.820 --> 00:06:54.840
And it's gives us an indication
of who's talking to who and

148
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:56.200
where they're coming from.

149
00:06:56.200 --> 00:06:59.200
And we could use that against
the logs to further correlate for

150
00:06:59.200 --> 00:07:01.310
the refiner understanding of information.

151
00:07:01.310 --> 00:07:02.580
Very important.

152
00:07:02.580 --> 00:07:04.986
Link that with most likely netstat,

153
00:07:04.986 --> 00:07:09.030
although Nbtstat would be more preferable,
cuz it gives us the open ports.

154
00:07:09.030 --> 00:07:12.660
So it's gonna help us correlate the port
information we see in the router or

155
00:07:12.660 --> 00:07:13.737
in the firewall logs.

156
00:07:13.737 --> 00:07:18.480
Nbtstat and NetBIOS names may not be of
a lot of value to us looking at a gateway

157
00:07:18.480 --> 00:07:21.970
device but
certainly inside of the network on the LAN

158
00:07:21.970 --> 00:07:25.210
that would be very helpful if we are
talking about potentially transmissions

159
00:07:25.210 --> 00:07:29.350
that went between two endpoints in
the LAN as opposed to over the WAN.

160
00:07:29.350 --> 00:07:32.630
And so nbtstat may be a valuable
source for additional information.

161
00:07:32.630 --> 00:07:34.240
Ipconfig/displaydns.

162
00:07:34.240 --> 00:07:35.770
Look at the name resolver cache.

163
00:07:35.770 --> 00:07:37.820
That would be helpful to
correlate against router and

164
00:07:37.820 --> 00:07:41.970
firewall logs to do some of the crosswalk
against URLs, and source and

165
00:07:41.970 --> 00:07:44.800
destination IP mapping
that we'd wanna validate.

166
00:07:44.800 --> 00:07:47.478
My point is and we've talked about
this before in other episodes.

167
00:07:47.478 --> 00:07:52.169
Especially in the very first set of
episodes we did for CHFI, where we really

168
00:07:52.169 --> 00:07:57.467
laid out the methodological foundations of
what it means to be a incident responder.

169
00:07:57.467 --> 00:08:00.799
To understand how to be a certified
hacking forensic investigator and

170
00:08:00.799 --> 00:08:02.275
deal with digital forensics.

171
00:08:02.275 --> 00:08:06.401
You have to really think, like an incident
responder because that is in essentially

172
00:08:06.401 --> 00:08:08.360
what you are doing at some level.

173
00:08:08.360 --> 00:08:10.720
And in order to carry out those
activities, think about that,

174
00:08:10.720 --> 00:08:13.530
have that in our minds,
we have to understand and

175
00:08:13.530 --> 00:08:16.370
really think about the fact that
one datapoint is never enough.

176
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:18.250
It may indicate to us
that there's a pattern,

177
00:08:18.250 --> 00:08:22.630
may indicate to us there's a path, gives
us direction, gives us point of access,

178
00:08:22.630 --> 00:08:26.000
tells us, that we should begin
our search and start to look.

179
00:08:26.000 --> 00:08:30.120
But it doesn't provide the definitive
authoritative last word on the subject.

180
00:08:30.120 --> 00:08:33.040
We have to have multiple points of
reference for that data to ensure its

A lot of areas still to go, but

32
00:01:35.930 --> 00:01:38.560

35

37

One or more distinct locations with

39

42

43

What are the do's and don'ts,

44

What are the key players, who are the big

45
00:02:21.470 --> 00:02:27.340
Certainly Microsoft comes to mind,

46
00:02:27.340 --> 00:02:32.293
Open SQL products, Postgres, and

47
00:02:32.293 --> 00:02:37.130
databases of a variety of types,
pop up and should be on our radar.

48
00:02:37.130 --> 00:02:41.670
And so we're gonna have to interact with
them, understand the structure of data,

49
00:02:41.670 --> 00:02:44.070
understand the tables
the data may live in.

50
00:02:44.070 --> 00:02:46.642
Understand how we read those tables,
interact with them, see them,

51
00:02:46.642 --> 00:02:47.481
what that looks like.

52
00:02:47.481 --> 00:02:50.764
And we have to really be thinking about
that thought process as we get started.

53
00:02:50.764 --> 00:02:53.956
Because we have to understand the types
of files and the structure that we

54
00:02:53.956 --> 00:02:57.269
are gonna encounter, in order to figure
about how to safeguard that data.

55
00:02:57.269 --> 00:03:00.821
Examine it forensically, but
also make sure we don't miss anything,

56
00:03:00.821 --> 00:03:02.600
we don't leave data behind.

57

For instance, when we go to look for

58

59

We may have the ability to understand, and

61
00:03:19.220 --> 00:03:24.070
Maybe there is a contacts database, a list

62
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:26.820
There's all sorts of stuff that
can go into databases, and

63
00:03:26.820 --> 00:03:27.940
we have to think about that.

64
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:30.162
So jumping in the beginning
of our conversations there,

65
00:03:30.162 --> 00:03:31.700
is where we're gonna spend some time.

66
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:37.156
Microsoft as the provider of SQL,
their flagship database product.

67
00:03:37.156 --> 00:03:41.277
Probably, certainly one of the very

68
00:03:41.277 --> 00:03:43.240
the Enterprise side today.

69
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:48.260
We certainly bump into Oracle,
we bump into IBM's DB2, Informix,

70
00:03:48.260 --> 00:03:50.560
all sorts of databases that are out there.

71
00:03:50.560 --> 00:03:54.510
But Microsoft does certainly wind up being
one of the most prevalent ones we will

72
00:03:54.510 --> 00:03:57.690
often come up against, and
therefore have to spend time with.

73
00:03:57.690 --> 00:04:01.730
There are three distinct types of files
that tend to make up Microsoft SQL

74
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:06.070
databases, the primary data file,
the secondary data files.

75
00:04:06.070 --> 00:04:09.170
There may be more than one, they are
optional, so we may have different ones,

76
00:04:09.170 --> 00:04:10.660
typically user-defined.

77
00:04:10.660 --> 00:04:14.860
And they are gonna store user data,
so we may see one or more of those.

78
00:04:14.860 --> 00:04:19.990
And the transaction logs, as a set
of files that hold log information.

79
00:04:19.990 --> 00:04:24.660
Those are gonna be the three key
defining file types or types of files,

80
00:04:24.660 --> 00:04:27.610
categories of files, that we see and
we have to investigate.

81
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:29.866
So let's talk about each one for
a minute, primary data file,

82
00:04:29.866 --> 00:04:31.838
that's the start-up information for
the database.

83
00:04:31.838 --> 00:04:36.318
This is where we are gonna find all
the other information that points to other

84
00:04:36.318 --> 00:04:37.723
files in the database.

85
00:04:37.723 --> 00:04:41.188
You can think of this as almost like
the map in the configuration file, that

86
00:04:41.188 --> 00:04:44.985
tells us how to manage the data, where
things are, and how they interact with it.

87
00:04:44.985 --> 00:04:48.392
User data and objects are stored in
this file, or in secondary files,

88
00:04:48.392 --> 00:04:49.856
depending on the structure.

89
00:04:49.856 --> 00:04:57.490
And every database has one primary data
file, and the extension is typically .mdf.

90
00:04:57.490 --> 00:05:02.652
Mary Data Frank, right, or
Mary Delta Frank, I suppose, right?

91
00:05:02.652 --> 00:05:05.307
So .mdf will be the extension for
the primary data file.

92
00:05:05.307 --> 00:05:09.829
As a forensics investigator, especially
one focused in the Microsoft world, we

93
00:05:09.829 --> 00:05:14.033
would wanna know that, would be important
that we go after the right files.

94
00:05:14.033 --> 00:05:16.487
And not just scoop up any kind of file,
but

95
00:05:16.487 --> 00:05:20.750
specifically certain kinds that
will yield information for us.

96
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:23.221
So, .mdf will be the primary
data file extension.

97
00:05:23.221 --> 00:05:27.348
Secondary data file, as I mentioned,
optional, user-defined, may or

98
00:05:27.348 --> 00:05:28.404
may not have them.

99
00:05:28.404 --> 00:05:31.776
They're spread across multiple disks,
wherever we're storing our data, so

100
00:05:31.776 --> 00:05:33.248
they can be in a variety of places.

101
00:05:33.248 --> 00:05:37.651
The extension for this will be .ndf,

102
00:05:37.651 --> 00:05:42.747
dot N as in No, Delta, Frank, so N-D-F.

103
00:05:42.747 --> 00:05:46.235
That will be our secondary data files,
typically plural.

104
00:05:46.235 --> 00:05:50.670
And our transaction log files,
again, we will have multiples there.

105
00:05:50.670 --> 00:05:53.979
They are used to restore or recover
the database, if we have a problem.

106
00:05:53.979 --> 00:05:57.496
Every item that is going to be entered
into the database, every transaction,

107
00:05:57.496 --> 00:06:01.011
in other words, that we entertain,
that is committed, that is successful,

108
00:06:01.011 --> 00:06:02.367
will be written into the log.

109
00:06:02.367 --> 00:06:07.284
So we can walk backwards and re-invent
that data, or walk forwards and restore,

110
00:06:07.284 --> 00:06:09.030
whatever we need to do.

111
00:06:09.030 --> 00:06:12.240
So we use the log as a validation tool,
and

112
00:06:12.240 --> 00:06:16.060
as a mechanism to authoritatively say,
what should be in the database, right.

113
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:18.270
This is our written
record of what's gone on.

114
00:06:18.270 --> 00:06:21.680
There must be at least one log file
per database, may be more than one.

115
00:06:21.680 --> 00:06:27.340
The extension for log files, .ldf,
dot Larry Delta Frank, L-D-F.

116
00:06:27.340 --> 00:06:31.413
>> Do you think it was coincidental
that they did L, M, and N in succession?

117
00:06:31.413 --> 00:06:34.084
>> Perhaps.

118
00:06:34.084 --> 00:06:37.095
>> [LAUGH]
>> Perhaps, I had not thought of that.

119
00:06:37.095 --> 00:06:38.201
>> Or it was there,
I thought it was interesting.

120
00:06:38.201 --> 00:06:42.210
>> I, that is, kudos, sir, kudos.

121
00:06:42.210 --> 00:06:44.576
>> But a easy way, like a nice
little mnemonic for you to remember.

122
00:06:44.576 --> 00:06:45.598
>> But a good way to think about it,
absolutely, right?

123
00:06:45.598 --> 00:06:49.786
>> L, M and N [CROSSTALK]
>> Yes, although M primary, secondary N,

124
00:06:49.786 --> 00:06:52.062
I mean you'd have to just
understand the logic,

Wouldn't be in traditional

55
00:02:22.239 --> 00:02:26.777
in multiple geographies, multiple

56
00:02:26.777 --> 00:02:31.726

57
00:02:31.726 --> 00:02:35.538
one or more cloud vendors that may or

58

And therefore be easily aligned with

59
00:02:39.924 --> 00:02:41.820

60

So there's this differentiation around

61
00:02:46.070 --> 00:02:49.790
And to that end, the deletion of data

62
00:02:49.790 --> 00:02:53.850

multi-geographical

64
00:02:58.060 --> 00:03:03.405

65
00:03:03.405 --> 00:03:06.345
or reasonable surety, that data has or

has not been securely destroyed or

67

another way of thinking about it on one or

68
00:03:14.947 --> 00:03:17.537
Yeah, you see these blinking

69
00:03:17.537 --> 00:03:20.947

refer to the fact that this could be

70

data center infrastructure

71

72
00:03:28.518 --> 00:03:32.898
If this was a physical data center

73

we had to then,

74

75

76

77

78

Probably go through
the legal challenges and

79
00:03:49.420 --> 00:03:53.230
concerns associated with accessing

80

Most likely get whatever passes for
a court order or a ruling from a judge

81
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:02.920
in that municipality, in that locality,
whatever that requires, wherever we are.

82
00:04:02.920 --> 00:04:07.450
And even then, when we show up,
there may still be a process and

83
00:04:07.450 --> 00:04:10.920
a thought process around how we're gonna
be able to execute that search warrant,

84
00:04:10.920 --> 00:04:13.230
is different by county and
different by incident.

85
00:04:13.230 --> 00:04:15.550
We have to partner with
local law enforcement.

86
00:04:15.550 --> 00:04:19.680
They may or may not have a working
relationship with the provider,

87
00:04:19.680 --> 00:04:23.270
the provider may or
may not choose to comply right away.

88
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:27.178
They may want to examine that order,
have their legal team involve.

89
00:04:27.178 --> 00:04:31.150
Sometime these become retracted of
things that have to be dealt with.

90
00:04:31.150 --> 00:04:34.120
I'm not suggesting the cloud provider

91
00:04:34.120 --> 00:04:35.885
There's a legal requirement on the table.

92
00:04:35.885 --> 00:04:39.810
They do have to comply, but

93
00:04:39.810 --> 00:04:42.890
We may not be able to show up and

94
00:04:42.890 --> 00:04:45.900
and there may be very tightly
constrained conditions

95
00:04:45.900 --> 00:04:47.790

96

We may have to walk through

97
00:04:51.030 --> 00:04:56.050
not may have to, most likely will
have to being escorted by one or

98
00:04:56.050 --> 00:04:59.440
more security individuals or
oversight individuals.

99
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:02.710
We may not be given direct
access to the material we seek.

100
00:05:02.710 --> 00:05:06.140
There may be a designated, duly appointed

101
00:05:06.140 --> 00:05:09.210
that will go execute the warrant

102
00:05:09.210 --> 00:05:13.116
And after we do the gathering of the data,
the removal of the hard drives,

103
00:05:13.116 --> 00:05:16.203
whatever may be, and we may or
may not be allowed to watch.

104
00:05:16.203 --> 00:05:19.101
We may or may not be able to
drive that process, we may or

105
00:05:19.101 --> 00:05:23.322
may not be able to oversee it, and we may

106
00:05:23.322 --> 00:05:27.640
they bring us what passes for the data and
complies with the search warrant.

107
00:05:27.640 --> 00:05:30.980
So there's a lot of ways this may
play out, we have to understand that.

108
00:05:30.980 --> 00:05:34.800
So deletion of data, revocation of
that ,is a significant challenge for

109
00:05:34.800 --> 00:05:35.730
us in the cloud.

110
00:05:35.730 --> 00:05:38.670
Recovery of overwritten data kind
of falls into the same category.

111
00:05:38.670 --> 00:05:39.830
Where is the data?

112
00:05:39.830 --> 00:05:41.780
Do we have access to the physical medium?

113
00:05:41.780 --> 00:05:44.861
Can we get to the NAS network
attach storage, to SAN,

114
00:05:44.861 --> 00:05:46.890
storage area network system.

115
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:49.040
If so, how does that work?

116
00:05:49.040 --> 00:05:51.460
Are we gonna be able to work
forensically on that drive?

117
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:54.650
There's a lot of questions and
concerns, right.

118
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:58.425
Interoperability of Cloud service
providers, if we're hosting And

119
00:05:58.425 --> 00:06:00.375
dealing with multiple cloud scenarios.

120
00:06:00.375 --> 00:06:03.425
Do cloud providers have
interoperability on their platforms?

121
00:06:03.425 --> 00:06:05.825
Will they talk with other cloud providers?

122
00:06:05.825 --> 00:06:09.295
Do they provide backwards
compatibility with our tool sets?

123
00:06:09.295 --> 00:06:10.775
There's a lot of concerns here.

124
00:06:10.775 --> 00:06:13.795
A lot o these providers
are running proprietary networks.

125
00:06:13.795 --> 00:06:16.915
They build their own hardware,
they have their own operating systems,

126
00:06:16.915 --> 00:06:19.220
and they have their own
tool sets to manage them.

127
00:06:19.220 --> 00:06:24.170
While data formats are somewhat
standardized, that doesn't necessarily

128
00:06:24.170 --> 00:06:28.210
mean that our tools will execute
properly in those environments.

129
00:06:28.210 --> 00:06:32.440
And we may have to rely on the provider
and their tool sets to gather the data,

130
00:06:32.440 --> 00:06:36.500
whether it's forensically sound or
not, it is up for conversation and

131
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:37.530
debate in some cases.

132
00:06:37.530 --> 00:06:39.130
So, that can be an issue.

133
00:06:39.130 --> 00:06:40.730
What about single point of failure?

134
00:06:40.730 --> 00:06:44.860
You have the cloud represents
a broadly scalable and

135
00:06:44.860 --> 00:06:49.775
broadly geographically dispersed
grid like environment.

136
00:06:49.775 --> 00:06:52.445
But that doesn't mean that there
aren't singly points of failure.

137
00:06:52.445 --> 00:06:56.043
It just means there are fewer and
farther between right?

138
00:06:56.043 --> 00:07:01.335
But, a single point of failure in terms
of an on ramp to the cloud, a band width

139
00:07:01.335 --> 00:07:05.635
access point, perhaps a work station
that's primarily used to do that or that

140
00:07:05.635 --> 00:07:10.870
is downloaded, the software the API access
or whatever it may be to access that.

141
00:07:10.870 --> 00:07:15.500
Perhaps key management and key storage, if
we only have a single copy of that key or

142
00:07:15.500 --> 00:07:18.070
access to it through one
dedicated workstation,

143
00:07:18.070 --> 00:07:20.930
can all present potential
single points of failure.

144
00:07:20.930 --> 00:07:24.390
Nothing like waking up on a Monday morning
and finding out your encryption key is

145
00:07:24.390 --> 00:07:27.200

or a key escrow and

146
00:07:27.200 --> 00:07:30.320
a key recovery mechanism, to ensure
that you can get back to the data.

147
00:07:30.320 --> 00:07:32.820
At that point, it's probably good
to think about going on vacation.

148
00:07:32.820 --> 00:07:33.660
>> Yeah.
[LAUGHS]

00:07:33.660 --> 00:07:34.490

00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:35.330
with that, right?

151
00:07:35.330 --> 00:07:37.950
No, I'm not on call for
the the next month, that's somebody else.

152
00:07:37.950 --> 00:07:41.261
Right, detection of malicious activity,
this can be initial in the cloud for

153
00:07:41.261 --> 00:07:43.182
a lot of reasons we've
all ready discussed.

154
00:07:43.182 --> 00:07:44.581
It may not be our systems,

155
00:07:44.581 --> 00:07:48.333
it maybe another tenant,
another customer totally unrelated to us,

156
00:07:48.333 --> 00:07:52.481
that house the malicious activity
happening that is the origination point.

157
00:07:52.481 --> 00:07:54.742
How do we diagnose that
as an investigator?

158
00:07:54.742 --> 00:07:56.551
How do we do we track that back?

159
00:07:56.551 --> 00:08:00.295
We need the help of the cloud provider, if
they're not willing to play ball with us,

160
00:08:00.295 --> 00:08:03.725
it becomes very difficult, if not
impossible to deal with these things, and

161
00:08:03.725 --> 00:08:05.840
this is a significant challenge for us.

162
00:08:05.840 --> 00:08:09.845
Real time investigations are not
often possible, as I pointed out.

163
00:08:09.845 --> 00:08:13.429
The cloud provider is first and
foremost interested in supporting and

164
00:08:13.429 --> 00:08:16.890
maintaining their operating
environment to earn their money.

165
00:08:16.890 --> 00:08:18.540
They're not interested
in delaying that for

166
00:08:18.540 --> 00:08:21.590
any reason,
unless absolutely compelled to by law.

167
00:08:21.590 --> 00:08:24.750
Which means they have no
compelling interest to be nice and

168
00:08:24.750 --> 00:08:28.650
bend over backwards to help us out, unless
somebody's threatening them to do so.

169
00:08:28.650 --> 00:08:29.240
Let me be clear.

170
00:08:29.240 --> 00:08:33.360
I'm not trying to cast a bad or in any
way negative light on cloud providers.

171
00:08:33.360 --> 00:08:36.080
I'm not suggesting that
they don't follow the law.

172
00:08:36.080 --> 00:08:39.250
I'm not suggesting that they
don't want to do the right thing.

173
00:08:39.250 --> 00:08:42.450
I'm just being realistic with you about
the fact that they're running their

174
00:08:42.450 --> 00:08:45.380
business and if you're trying
to get in the way of that,

175
00:08:45.380 --> 00:08:48.520
there has to be a compelling reason for
them to allow you to do that.

176
00:08:48.520 --> 00:08:51.140
Or it just doesn't make sense for them.

177
00:08:51.140 --> 00:08:52.310
That's the reality.

178
00:08:52.310 --> 00:08:57.030
You're a nuisance, in other words, and
a delay for them and unless they are being

179
00:08:57.030 --> 00:09:01.110
told by a court of law that they have
to comply, in which case they do.

180
00:09:01.110 --> 00:09:04.160
Let's be fair and be honest,
they certainly will do that.

181
00:09:04.160 --> 00:09:07.533
Then there's really probably,
not an overwhelming compelling reason for

182
00:09:07.533 --> 00:09:11.350
them to move heaven and earth to allow
you to do your real time investigations.

183
00:09:11.350 --> 00:09:15.010
So you do have to understand when you
show up in one of these scenarios within

184
00:09:15.010 --> 00:09:19.280
certain response and forensics in
mind around cloud providers and

185
00:09:19.280 --> 00:09:23.340
cloud activities that there
may not be the same agenda

186
00:09:23.340 --> 00:09:26.740
on the cloud provider's table
today as there is on your table.

187
00:09:26.740 --> 00:09:28.540
And those two things may clash.

188
00:09:28.540 --> 00:09:32.050
And because they hold the keys to
the kingdom, they're gonna win, right?

189
00:09:32.050 --> 00:09:35.100
Unless you brought law enforcement with
you and a piece of paper that says,

190
00:09:35.100 --> 00:09:37.300
sorry you've gotta stop what you're doing.

191
00:09:37.300 --> 00:09:38.958
So, just make sure you're aware of that.

192
00:09:38.958 --> 00:09:44.480
You're not gonna rely on the niceties and
the beneficiary of being nice is a good

193
00:09:44.480 --> 00:09:47.520
thing, but the reality is they might just
not be interested in talking to you.

194
00:09:47.520 --> 00:09:50.170
You might not get past
the lobby unless you've got

195
00:09:50.170 --> 00:09:52.760
a search warrant because they just
aren't gonna pay attention to you.

196
00:09:52.760 --> 00:09:53.510
>> Adam, really quickly.

197
00:09:53.510 --> 00:09:56.880
It was making me think that,
if I'm sharing hardware resources,

198
00:09:56.880 --> 00:10:01.970
such as storage, and
maybe even a same drive.

199
00:10:01.970 --> 00:10:04.240
We're sharing a drive between
two different companies.

200
00:10:04.240 --> 00:10:08.230
When I go back to my first
responder kind of idea of

201
00:10:08.230 --> 00:10:10.900
we're not supposed to modify
the drive in any way.

202
00:10:10.900 --> 00:10:12.630
We're not supposed to
make writes to the drive.

203
00:10:14.590 --> 00:10:17.650
If I'm not making writes but
another company is making writes

204
00:10:17.650 --> 00:10:20.720
to the exact same drive, does that
corrupt the integrity of the data?

205
00:10:20.720 --> 00:10:23.190
>> Well remember, it's not that you
would necessarily share the same drive.

206
00:10:23.190 --> 00:10:24.420
I mean, yes, theoretically.

207
00:10:24.420 --> 00:10:30.080
Certainly in terms of a large drive
enclosure, there may be in a raid

208
00:10:30.080 --> 00:10:36.970
scenario, or in some sort of large
scenario where we're using a SAN,

209
00:10:36.970 --> 00:10:40.170
storage area network, and maybe
striping data, doing different things.

210
00:10:40.170 --> 00:10:44.420
There may very well be hard
drives in common, right?

211
00:10:44.420 --> 00:10:48.170
But the reality is,
we're creating partitionable space, right,

212
00:10:48.170 --> 00:10:51.930
for each of these individual customers,
if you wanna just think about it that way.

213
00:10:51.930 --> 00:10:56.940
And so my company's data is
going onto the same common

214
00:10:56.940 --> 00:11:01.540
storage area network as Daniel let's say
your company's data but we're not gonna be

215
00:11:01.540 --> 00:11:06.550
in the same logical space writing,
reading to and from let's say.

216
00:11:06.550 --> 00:11:08.910
That data or those data sets, right,

217
00:11:08.910 --> 00:11:12.070
because obviously we're not sharing
common data, but those data sets

218
00:11:12.070 --> 00:11:15.520
are stored differently from a logical
space management perspective.

219
00:11:15.520 --> 00:11:18.630

44
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:03.417

45
00:02:03.417 --> 00:02:06.620

46

47

48
00:02:11.820 --> 00:02:15.620

49
00:02:15.620 --> 00:02:18.830

50
00:02:18.830 --> 00:02:21.920
Or if we're not given that right or
opportunity because we don't have access

51
00:02:21.920 --> 00:02:25.985

52
00:02:25.985 --> 00:02:27.405
We give you then try to hack a way at it,

54
00:02:29.975 --> 00:02:34.205

55
00:02:34.205 --> 00:02:37.105
the item, or whatever it is to execute,
move through the system,

56
00:02:37.105 --> 00:02:39.585
whatever the case may be, unchallenged.

57
00:02:39.585 --> 00:02:43.705
Not knowing what's inside the black box,

58
00:02:43.705 --> 00:02:47.280
We do not allow it to run, we don't

59
00:02:47.280 --> 00:02:50.780
We throw it away, in other words,

60
00:02:50.780 --> 00:02:53.060
And those are really the only

61
00:02:53.060 --> 00:02:55.830
Either we can decrypt,

00:02:55.830 --> 00:02:58.980

00:02:58.980 --> 00:02:59.541
Or do we not?

00:02:59.541 --> 00:03:01.960
And if we don't,

00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:03.100

66
00:03:03.100 --> 00:03:05.340
But that's what the whole

00:05:07.610 --> 00:05:09.340
Cuz that's what we're doing.

00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:12.860
Right, we have a dropper, this typically

So the dropper itself may be a form

115
00:05:31.803 --> 00:05:35.645
it essentially covers and

00:05:35.645 --> 00:05:39.680

00:05:39.680 --> 00:05:42.982
So a dropper is almost like a combination

00:05:42.982 --> 00:05:44.310

Because it will envelop the malware code,

00:05:53.026 --> 00:05:55.445
But also has the download

00:05:59.300 --> 00:06:00.180

125
00:06:04.110 --> 00:06:08.110
Exploits, one or more code the attackers

00:06:08.110 --> 00:06:09.910

00:06:09.910 --> 00:06:14.190
So exploit or exploits are the things

00:06:14.190 --> 00:06:16.580

00:06:16.580 --> 00:06:19.470

00:06:19.470 --> 00:06:23.655

00:06:23.655 --> 00:06:25.409

00:06:25.409 --> 00:06:28.607

134
00:06:33.202 --> 00:06:36.152
Obfuscators, programs that can seal or

00:06:36.152 --> 00:06:40.018

136
00:06:40.018 --> 00:06:44.167

00:06:44.167 --> 00:06:48.440

138
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:53.050
Polymorphic techniques, where we mask and
morph every time, where we

139
00:06:53.050 --> 00:06:57.810

140
00:06:57.810 --> 00:07:00.280
There's a bunch of stuff

141
00:07:00.280 --> 00:07:03.568
That general class of activity

142
00:07:03.568 --> 00:07:06.340
But a specific, very,
very uniquely defined and

143
00:07:06.340 --> 00:07:09.870
narrowly tailored example of using

144
00:07:09.870 --> 00:07:12.890
is carved out and called the crypter,

145
00:07:12.890 --> 00:07:17.097
Packers, pieces of software that

146
00:07:17.097 --> 00:07:20.087

147
00:07:20.087 --> 00:07:24.885

00:07:24.885 --> 00:07:30.010

149
00:07:30.010 --> 00:07:33.093
And then payload's part of the malware

150
00:07:33.093 --> 00:07:33.606

151
00:07:33.606 --> 00:07:37.090
Whatever that is, that is gonna

00:07:37.090 --> 00:07:39.168
from the bad actor's perspective,

153
00:07:39.168 --> 00:07:43.523
you'll really be the piece of the puzzle

154
00:07:43.523 --> 00:07:47.696
to break in and get the file, or
whatever they're looking to do, right?

155
00:07:47.696 --> 00:07:51.611
The payload is the injection of the bad
code that we are using and the outcome

156
00:07:51.611 --> 00:07:55.674
of that, that's the pay load that we
are gonna go after, that kind of thing.

157
00:07:55.674 --> 00:07:57.160
So keep that in mind.

158
00:07:57.160 --> 00:08:01.095
And when we talk about all these different
components we have to analyze malware to

159
00:08:01.095 --> 00:08:01.672
find them.

160
00:08:01.672 --> 00:08:05.224
Now we have two types of techniques
that we use for malware analysis,

161
00:08:05.224 --> 00:08:07.560
two traditional ones, there are variants.

162
00:08:07.560 --> 00:08:10.730
But traditionally we think
of static analysis and

163
00:08:10.730 --> 00:08:15.150
we also think about Dynamic
analysis of malware code.

164
00:08:15.150 --> 00:08:19.383
Static analysis implies that we're looking
at the code, breaking it down looking at

165
00:08:19.383 --> 00:08:23.617
literally code review line by line, we're
going through without executing the code

166
00:08:23.617 --> 00:08:26.992
which is the key to finding difference
between the two approaches.

167
00:08:26.992 --> 00:08:30.759
So we're reading the code offline,
we may use a decompiler or

168
00:08:30.759 --> 00:08:35.265
text editor to break open and examine
the executable or the code package.

169
00:08:35.265 --> 00:08:40.564
Trying to decompress decompile and
to deconstruct the code looking at it and

170
00:08:40.564 --> 00:08:43.462
then when we are dynamically examining or

171
00:08:43.462 --> 00:08:48.295
executing it inside of some sort
of sandbox or isolated system.

172
00:08:48.295 --> 00:08:51.227
To see what the outcome of
that particular code may be so

173
00:08:51.227 --> 00:08:54.992
static versus dynamic are the two
different kinds of malware analysis

174
00:08:54.992 --> 00:08:59.034
techniques that we engage in,
wanna make sure we're familiar with that.

175
00:08:59.034 --> 00:09:01.058
Sometimes static analysis and

176
00:09:01.058 --> 00:09:06.045
behavioral analysis will be added along

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Adam discuss how E-Mail can play an important role when it comes to investigating email crimes. Adam explains the client/server architecture and explains the differences between common methods such as SMTP, POP3, and IMAP4. episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee continue their discussion around E-Mail crimes. First, Adam walks thru an 8 step method best practice guide.  Adam shares a useful link, http://centralops.net to help perform certain tests. They them cover different encoding methods such as MIME, Uuencoding, and BinHex. Next they discuss where logs are retained within different OS environments. Specifically, Adam shows files locations within  Linux and Windows server environment. Lastly, U.S laws relating E-Mail crimes are noted.
